Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 06:40PM - edited Jun 28, 2012 06:49PM by Melrosemelrose HAIR  (I know that this topic is not an easy one for us but here we go!!!) As each of you are well aware of, hair is affected by the chemo.  this is just a very quick read on hair loss just to give you a brief idea of what to expect.  Handling the hair loss is very personal and so the decision is up to each of you as to if and when you cut your hair and how much you cut.  There are no written guidelines as to how much to cut or when to cut.  It is what you feel the most comfortable doing.  Whatever you decide to do, take control over the hair before it takes control over you.  I know you won't understand that statement now but you will later. What to expect:  Most people experience scalp pain about a week after the first chemo round.  The scalp can become very sensitive, tingle, itch and even be sore.  The hair loss may begin within 14 days after the beginning of chemo.  It will come out a little at first and then the hair loss will increase.  Please be aware that when you wash your hair when you are in the shower, you will become very much aware of the hair loss.    What to do:  Once the hair loss increases, the hair will be everywhere.  I used a lint roller to get the hair off of me, my clothes and my pillow and bed.  This is the time when most decide to cut the hair short or have it cut very very close to the scalp.  Just remember the decision is up to you as to how much to cut because it is a very emotional time.  No matter what you do, just remember you are still beautiful now matter how much hair you have on your head.  There are lots of options for head coverings--- hats, scarves, Buffs, wigs, etc.  It's just a matter of personal choice.  You can contact the American Cancer Society and attend a Look Good Feel Good session to get a make up session and can even get a free wig.  Also the TLC catalogue is a great source for headcovers, wigs, etc. There is a chemo board thread called Hair, Hair, Hair that can also be a great support and resource for you.  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/707348?page=527#idx_15793 The rest of the hair:  Loss of the eyebrows, eye lashes, leg and arm hair and down south can also occur.  Sometimes it occurs during the chemotherapy or after the completion of chemotherapy.  My short hair story:I opted to cut my short bob to a very very short boy haircut about 2 1/2 weeks after my first treatment because I got so annoyed with the hair everywhere. I was the one who took control and made five little ponytails of the longest sections of my bob and clipped those ponytails off myself.  It was a very liberating experience for me since I took control and did the cutting myself.  My husband used his trusty electric clippers with a 1 inch guard to clean up the sides and back so I now had a cute short boy pixie cut.  I opted not to shave my head and glad I did not.  I recently had my fourth round of chemo and have not loss all of my hair.  I have a thin veil of hair with stubs growing.  I'm glad that I did not shave it since some of the gals on one of the chemo threads I'm on wish that they had not shaved their heads.  It was my decision before I started to have to not shave my head close because I wanted to see if the chemo would take out all of my hair and felt that the transition from having waist length hair in February 2012 to being bald by May 2012 would be too much for me. Wishing each of you the best!!!  You can do this.... because you are each stronger than you know!!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 06:45PM Melrosemelrose wrote: FOR THOSE ICING NAILS DURING TAXOTERE INFUSION:  Always clear anything you want to do with your oncos.  You will need to clear it with your onco about icing since not all oncos will allow icing during the Taxotere infusion.  At the suggestion of my onco, I am using clear nail polish on my nails to help keep them strong and also icing the nails to help prevent nail damage which is a side effect of Taxotere.  She suggested that use Sally Hansen Strong As Nails Clear Polish but I switched to Essie polish since it doesn't chip as much as the Sally Hansen brand.  Essie polish costs more but for someone like me who never used nail polish before chemo, the fewer times I have to apply polish the better.  I don't mani/pedis but some do.  I'd rather avoid the germ issue at nail salons and taking of a chance of getting nicked.  ICING :

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2012 07:52PM Melrosemelrose wrote: FOR THOSE GETTING A NEULASTA SHOT AFTER YOUR ROUND OF CHEMO:  You may want to try taking regular 24 hour Claritin to help with the bone pain that may accompany the Neulasta shot.  There is an ongoing clinical trial evaluating Claritin to prevent the bone pain.  Here is the link:  (http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01311336?term=claritin&rank=3) According to the clinical trial, one takes the Claritin (10 mg) once a day for 7 days beginning the day of the Neulasta treatment. I had my first Neulasta shot with my 3rd round of Cytoxan/Taxotere and took the Claritin.  I did not experience any bone pain.  The Claritin doesn't help everyone but it is worth a try since from my understanding the bone pain may be intense.  Just remember to ask your onco about trying the Claritin before you take it.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2012 teeballmom SusanHG123

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 06:26PM Melrosemelrose wrote: FOR THOSE HAVING FIRST TREATMENTS of CYTOXAN/TAXOTERE:  Hope this helps.  The first treatment may take longer because you are still learning the infusion center procedure.  You will probably get weighed and then your blood work may be taken to determine if your WBC is high enough for the treatment.  I also see my onco the day of my treatment and before I have my treatment.  So be prepared for things to take a little longer.  You may want to take some snacks/sandwich because you may get hungry.  You may also want to take a blanket/jacket to keep you warm during the treatment unless the infusion center has warmed blankets for its patients.  I'm lucky that mine does.  I usually wear the same outfit--- leggings & long sleeve knit shirt & men's undershirt--- so I can tell if I've gained weight between treatments.  I have my Taxotere infusion first and then have the Cytoxan infusion second.  Make sure you drink water/eat ice during the treatment to help prevent mouth sores and to start flushing that chemo through your body.  You will sit the entire time during the Taxotere infusion since you are icing.  However you definitely can get up and walk around with your IV pole during the Cytoxan.  That means don't curtail your fluid intake thinking that you can't use the restroom because you can definitely get up to take a walk or go to the restroom!!!!  Just ask the infusion nurse to unplug your IV pole from the electric plug.  My onco ordered Ativan in my IV along with the usual IV meds which helps me keep calm during my treatments. After the first treatment, keep drinking the fluids to help flush the chemo out of your body.  I know you may not feel like eating but try to eat 5-6 small meals every day.  A fed tummy is a happy tummy.  If your side effects start to escalate, call your onco to get some help asap.  Doesn't matter what time of day it is or what day of the week it is, just call.  They really want to help you get side effects under control and expect you to call.  GOOD LUCK ON THE FIRST TREATMENT!!!  WISHING MINIMAL SIDE EFFECTS FOR ALL!!!!  YOU CAN DO THIS.  Once you get through the first one, you need to say out loud " I AM DOING THIS!!!!"
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2012 teeballmom SusanHG123

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2012 06:03PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Glad to hear you ladies are getting the dental situations taken care of before the chemo.  You may also want to check to make sure you can use electric toothbrushes after you start chemo.  I was told to use soft manual toothbrushes to avoid any micro cuts to my gums from the electric toothbrush and not to use dental floss because I could further cut my gums.  Our mouths are really sensitive during the chemo because some of the side effects of chemo are mouth sores, thrush, etc.    I really miss my sonic care tooth brush because it really cleans so well.  But now I do my best to brush after every meal.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 05:44PM - edited Jun 28, 2012 05:45PM by Melrosemelrose For Those Having Ports Installed- Here are some questions to ask your onco/surgeon prior to having your port installed: I had my port installed when I had my UMX which was 6 weeks before I started chemo.  I was told my breast surgeon that the port area would be sore for a while.  There are some who have the port installed a few days or the day before the first round of chemo.  They usually ask for a numbing spray at the infusion center to numb the area since the EMLA cream cannot be used on an recently sutured area.  Hope this helps!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 05:54PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Soltantio- EMLA cream is by prescription only.  You can ask your onco for a prescription.  If you don't get one, you can ask the infusion nurse for some numbing spray.  If you can't get that, ask the nurse to numb the area with ice.  Sarassister- Not everyone gets all of the side effects that are known.  The severity/degree of side effects vary from person to person.  That is one good thing about the chemo-- the amount of chemo is specific to each person-- dosage is determined by a person's weight.  The fact that your wonderful sister is not experiencing minimal side effects is great.  It does not mean that the chemo is not working.    The side effect that she is experiencing is neuropathy and hopefully is temporary.  She may become more tired with each round of treatment.  Prior to each treatment, she probably has blood work to determine if her white blood count is high enough for that round of chemo and to check her red blood count to see if she is anemic.  Chemo does affect the blood cells so that would be an indicator that the chemo is doing its job.  Wishing your sister and everyone in your family the best.  Thanks for being there for your sister.  I'm sure she knows how important your love and support is!!!  HUGS to you and yours.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2012 teeballmom SusanHG123

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 04:46AM Melrosemelrose wrote: curveball- PFC= post f*#k%ng chemo.  It is what you might think it means. How to keep a happy tummy during chemo-I almost forgot to tell you that you should try to eat 5-6 small meals rather than 3 big meals day.  Keeping something in your tummy constantly will help.  In short, a fed tummy is a happy tummy.  You probably need to take your anti-nausea meds with food since those drugs on an empty stomach may cause nausea.  Trying to figure out what to eat was starting to make my brain hurt so thank goodness the oncology navigator gave me that cookbook I mentioned above.  Drinking liquids is very boring and sometimes just plain untasty.  I sometimes put an orange slice in my water to help flavor it.  I also just add cut up fruit to my water (strawberries/berries/grapes). Eating watermelon and grapes can also help add fluids to your body.  You can also drink gatorade.  I sometimes drink decaffinated ice tea.  I also fill up two 32 ounce Nalgene bottles so I just drink out of two containers.  For some reason the idea of drinking multiple glasses of water seems undaunting to me and keeping track of the number of glasses is not easy when one isn't feeling well. I had a one inch pixie cut at the beginning of my 2nd round of chemo.  That following week, the hair really started to go.  I tried not to panic about the hair loss.  I used a lint roller to get the hair off of my neck, back, etc., my bed, my clothes.  Yes, there was plenty of hair in the shower drain but after a while, the hair loss subsided.  I never have lost all of my hair.  I have sparse hair all over my head and now heading into the 5th round tomorrow.  I have some stubbies and some peach fuzz.  I don't know if that new growth will fall out after these last two rounds but at least it gives me hope that those little hair follicles are trying awfully hard to make hair again!!!!  I have a wig from the American Cancer Society ( it was free through its Look Good Feel Good program which you can check out on line) that sits in a ziploc bag.  It's too hot to wear it and plus it just isn't me.  I wear hats, caps, bandanas and Buffs.  As your hair goes, just remember that you are beautiful no matter what!!! HUGS to each of you and hoping for minimal side effects for all.!!!! The first infusion is an anxious time but you will realize how doable chemo is and that you can do this!!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo July 2012 teeballmom SusanHG123

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 06:51PM Melrosemelrose wrote: curveball-Start counting from the date of your final chemo to be PFC.  I didn't start counting how many days until I got there since I knew that any point in time during my chemoland, my treatments could be delayed from a side effect or reaction to something.  I just never wanted to get my hopes up and dashed because of delays.  I take one chemo round at a time and hoping that after each round, I am able to have the next scheduled round.  It is only now as I head into #5, I am starting to see the end of my chemo journey in early August. Jennifer404 & swimmom01- The hair is very personal decision and choice that each makes with chemo.  There is not right way or wrong way here.  Whatever you decide to do, always take control over the hair before it takes control over you.  I can't explain that statement very well but I believe each of you will know what I mean when you reach that point.  I never shaved my head or had my hair clipped close to the scalp.  I've had a self/at home short short boy cut.  That occurred after my 2nd treatment and because I got annoyed with the hair being everywhere.  I made the 5 little pony tails and snipped those pony tails alone.  It was quite liberating and it controlled that hair being everywhere.  Yes, my hair has fallen out and I now a thin veil of hair all over my head.  I've scant wispy bangs and scant hair on the nape of my neck.  I decided before I had chemo that I would not be shaving my head since I wanted to see what the chemo regimen would actually do ( self science experiment) and felt that going from waist length hair to absolutely no hair was going to be a little too much for me.  I love how my head feels now with what hair I have, peach fuzz and some new stubbie growth.  My DH and DS rub my head and I tell them it's for good luck.  It is reassuring to know that those little stubborn hair follicles are trying to get on with growing hair despite that mean old chemo.   I have a free wig from the American Cancer Society Look Good Feel Good program and that poor little wig is having abandonment issues sitting in a zip loc bag.  I usually wear caps, bandanas, Buffs and straw fedora hats.  The wig just isn't me but the other head coverings are.  No matter what action you take, just remember that you are beautiful no matter what!!!! Wishing all of you gals on this thread the best with minimal side effects.

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2012 11:46AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Thought I'd share a little info about what happens after the first round of chemo since I'm heading into my last chemo in less than 2 weeks ( Cytoxan/Taxotere x 6). Let's keep our fingers crossed that everyone's side effects will continue to be minimal.  My first one was the worst and since then, they were not as bad.  However, one never knows since the side effects are cumulative.  I did notice that my eyes are tearing more; but not surprised.  Taxotere is also called " Taxo- tears" for a reason.  I also noticed that my burping has gotten better too.  I had a bout of tongue sores but rinsed several times a day with 1/4 teaspoon salt + 1/4 teaspoon baking soda + 1 cup of warm water solution.  I made a new fresh cup of rinse every time I rinsed my mouth.  I do have this burned tongue sensation that starts a few days after the chemo and lasts for at least another week afterwards.  It also signals that my taste buds are on vacation.  The texture of foods change and there are foods that I don't like to put in my mouth during that time because of the thick greasy feeling I have.  The week before I have my next round of chemo, I feel much better and less fatigued.   I can tell you that the fatigue factor has gotten more obvious to me after each round of chemo.  I know it is partial from the chemo itself and my body's ability to recover is taking a little longer.  I know my onco is watching my red blood count since it has continued to decline with chemo.  Fortunately, one can help that with an iron enriched diet.  I stopped using my sonicare toothbrush until after I finish with my chemo.  I spoke to my dentist before starting chemo and he as well as my onco said to use a soft manual toothbrush to avoid any microcuts/microabrasions to my gums.  Just want to avoid any means of infections during chemo treatment.  For Those taking A/C on 3 week regimen- Please don't feel like there is something not right with having dose dense chemo.  I know of at least one gal on the boards who is receiving her A/C chemo every 3 weeks like you.  If you go the chemocare.com website (which is the website founded by Scott Hamiliton, the former Olympic ice skater and cancer survivor) and read about your chemo regimen, you will find that the nadir period for both of those drugs begin during the 2nd week after the infusion and the recovery period for both is 3 weeks.  Here are the 2 links http://www.chemocare.com/bio/adriamycin.asp http://www.chemocare.com/bio/cytoxan.asp You will have the opportunity to give your body the chance to recover in time for the next round and you won't be heading into that next dose dense chemo before your body has recovered.  Most dose dense receive Neulasta or Neupogan shots the day after their infusions and are told they will receive them before they even start their chemo.  Although I am not on the A/C regimen, I did not start getting a Neulasta shot until after my 2nd round of chemo.  I developed a spikey high fever and was told by my onco that I would thereafter receive a Neulasta shot to help prevent that situation from reoccuring.  My onco doesn't give the Neulasta shot unless the patient demonstrates the need for one.  Hope this helps, ladies!!!  Wishing easy times this week for those in the Big Girl Chair this week and minimal side effects!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 06:54AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Itsalltemporary & Virginiab- I am 5 weeks PFC after 6 rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere.  I am participating in the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial which chemo protocal is 6 rounds.  I also knew before I volunteered for the clinical trial that I would be having 6 rounds of chemo.  So the idea of having just 4 rounds was not in the picture for me.  No matter what, I just wanted to do whatever I had to do to make sure the big nasty was truly gone and not lurking or travelling somewhere in my body.  Yes, I know it may feel like everyone else will be done and finished by the time you complete the 6 rounds but it has turned out not the case with me.  The women I started out with in chemo that are on different regimens are just now getting their last treatments of Taxol/Taxotere.  Once you've had the 3rd round of chemo, you are on the downhill side of your time in chemoland.  It means only 3 left, then 2 left and then only 1 left.   Patience, my friends..... patience.   FYI:  My hair fuzz started to make its comeback after the 4th round; it tried again after the 5th round and really made a big effort 3 weeks after my final chemo.  It was like my hair follicles said " Now is our time to blossom and comeback since we don't have to contend with that chemo anymore!" Wishing minimal side effects and easy times in the chemo chair!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2012 07:57PM Melrosemelrose wrote: FOR THOSE WHO HAVE A PORT FOR CHEMO :  You may want to ask your onco for a prescription for EMLA cream (lidocaine) so you can numb the port area before you leave home for your round of chemo.  If you forget to apply the EMLA cream or don't receive a prescription, ask the infusion nurse to spray the port area with numbing spray.  That way you won't feel the poke when the port is accessed.    If you receive a generic EMLA cream at the drug store, it may not come with any special coverings for the area to put on after you apply it.  In order to avoid getting the EMLA cream on your clothes and other places, just a 4 X 4 inch square of Glad Press N Seal plastic wrap to cover the area.  Make sure you avoid the temptation to spread the EMLA cream on the port area; I'm told that your fingers will be numb for quite a while!!!!

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2012 12:21PM Melrosemelrose wrote: I asked the same question about what day of the week to have chemo from prior chemo threads.  Most tried to schedule their chemos so that they would have the weekend to recover.  It also depends on what kind of chemo you are having and how much help you think you might need and have available when you are having a down time ( some have jobs or young children.)  I have my chemo on Tuesdays.  I'm okay Wednesday & Thursday.  Friday is the day that if I'm going to crash, it is that day!!  I rest Saturday & Sunday and good to go on Monday.  Steroids- Steroids may amp you up.  I take Decadron twice a day the day before chemo, the day of chemo and the day after chemo.  I don't sleep well at night for a few days after the first dosage since they keep me a little wired.  I don't get upset about the not sleeping as some do and just nap whenever.  Some take sleeping pills to help them sleep at night.  The steroids can also cause skin breakouts.

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2012 05:46AM - edited Jul 6, 2012 05:47AM by Melrosemelrose soltantio- Hopefully, your onco/infusion center provided you with a list of possible side effects of the chemo.  It helps so you have an idea of what the possible side effects can be.  Just because you are given that list, don't assume or presume that you will have every side effect and you will have the worst case of that side effect.  There are things you can do to help in preparation of treatment and after treatment such as make sure you eat 5-6 small meals, drink lots of fluids to help flush out the chemo; take your medications on time and with food and rest, etc.  I can't tell you if you will need to have anyone stay with you over the weekend.  It may be a good idea to have someone available if you need a little help or at least call to check on you.  I have two gal pals that call/text me a few days after my treatments to check on me to make sure I'm okay.  It's not like i need someone there 24/7 with me but it is great to have someone check on me periodically to see if I need anything.  As for having the flu like symptoms after receiving your treatment, you should know that right before you have  chemo, you will most likely have blood lab work done to make sure your blood counts are high enough to receive the treatment.  I hope that you are given a list of specific side effects to watch for that require you to call your onco immediately (ie high fever-- 100.4 or higher).  If you have any of those type of side effects/symptoms, you call your onco asap 24/7.  Doesn't matter if it's the weekend or in the evening or early morning.  I had a high spikey fever 11 days after my 2nd round and called my onco as soon as I realized that the fever wasn't coming down on its own.  She called in some antibotics for me and fortunately, I did not have to go to the ER.

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 07:50PM - edited Jul 16, 2012 05:15AM by Melrosemelrose winter_flower- Glad you found this thread.  You will find a lot of support here and on other chemo threads as well.  I'm on the April/May 2012 chemo hangout with a great group of gals who will give you support and help that you need.  In addition, it's just a great place to rant, rave and vent which we all need to do time to time.  Please feel free to go to that thread and ask any questions you may have.    If you are wanting to help getting prepared, please go to this link which is the first thread in the Chemo forum for Newbies.  You will find some great info to help you gather up things in preparation for chemo.  You don't have to purchase everything on that list but it gives you an idea of what one might need.  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/785189?page=1#idx_1  I am on a different chemo regimen as you( Cytoxan/Taxotere) but I know there are a few here who are have same A/C regimen as you.  Just know that one may or may not have all of the side effects that the regimen can have and those side effects that one has may not be that severe.  Whatever drugs that your oncologist prescribes for you for help prevent nausea, make sure you take them as prescribed whether or not you are experiencing nausea.  Take them on schedule and don't wait for the nausea to hit to take action.  If you start having problems with some of your side effects, let your oncologist know asap--- no matter what time of day it is or whether it is a week day or weekend.  In general, they want to help you but you've got to communicate with them to let them know what anti-nausea drugs are working and which ones are not.  It's their job to help you and you are not imposing upon them.  As for constipation, there are foods you can eat to help prevent that.  Prune juice, dried prunes ( I eat the Sunsweet Ones which are really moist and sweet), apple juice, wheat bran, other fuirts and veggies help.  I have two cookbooks which have been a great help to me--- Eating Well Through Cancer by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello, M.D.( this book was given to me at the cancer center where I get treatment) and the Cancer Fighting Kitchen by Rebecca Katz.  The Eating Well Through Cancer is a great book with grocery lists, recipes and what to eat when having certain side effects.  It took away all the guesswork I was trying to do searching and figuring out what to eat.  Hope this helps.  Wishing you the best!!!!  You can do this.... after the first treatment, you will need to say out loud, "I am doing this!!!"

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 11:18PM - edited Aug 1, 2012 02:46PM by Melrosemelrose I posted this info earlier and updated the info.  Hope it helps.    FOR THOSE GETTING A NEULASTA SHOT AFTER YOUR ROUND OF CHEMO:  You may want to try taking regular 24 hour Claritin to help with the bone pain that may accompany the Neulasta shot.  There is an ongoing clinical trial evaluating Claritin to prevent the bone pain.  Here is the link:  (clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NC...) According to the clinical trial, one takes the Claritin (10 mg) once a day for 7 days beginning the day of the Neulasta treatment. I had my first Neulasta shot with my 3rd round of Cytoxan/Taxotere and took the Claritin.  I did not experience any bone pain.  The Claritin doesn't help everyone but it is worth a try since from my understanding the bone pain may be intense.  I'm now heading into my last chemo next week (6 of 6 rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere) and no severe pain from the Neulasta shot that I have received since the 3rd round.  Just remember to ask your onco about trying the Claritin before you take it. I get my Neulasta shot in the tummy where there is some tummy fat.  In fact, I ask the nurse to give it to me there rather than in my arm.  It hurts less going in and I don't seem to have any post injection pain.  The nurse gives the shot to hold in my hand to warm it up before I receive the injection.  She then, slowly injects the shot which to help with injection pain. I've also read on the boards that you can take one Tylenol and one Motrin combo every 4-6 hours to help with the bone pain.  I do not take any Tylenol or Motrin or Advil after I get my chemo but I am cleared to take Tylenol or Advil by my onco.  Again, always ask your onco about what OTC pain meds you can take before you take any. Wishing minimal side effects for all!!!

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 06:21AM Melrosemelrose wrote: natl 12- Hope you are doing well.  You can help those red blood cells out by eating foods with lots of iron (red meat, liver (if you like it), dark green leafy veggies, spinach, iron fortified cereals and grains (Total, Cream of Wheat, rice).  My red blood counts started to drop during my rounds of chemo and fell just below the normal range.   I asked my onco about taking an iron supplement but she said she preferred that I got the iron from food rather than through a supplement.  That was fine with me since I'm not one to take meds/ supplements unless I absolutely have to.  Hopefully my red blood counts will slowly climb back to the normal range as I recover from the chemo.  If you have more questions about the iron foods, private message me and I'll give you more info. Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 07:07PM Melrosemelrose wrote: TAB55- When I met with my onco before I started chemo, she told me that I may not lose my leg hair and not to get too excited about not shaving.  Well, it definitely thinned out but stll have leg hair.  I also have all of my eyebrows, eyelashes and sparse hair down south.  I know that the brows and lashes may go once I finish chemo since that is what usually happens with my chemo regimen.  Oh well, it's just hair. Swimmom01- There are some advantages to having less head hair-- less time to wash hair, no hair brushing, save on shampoo anc haircut costs.  So much cooler in the summer, especially this hot one we are having now!!!!  I still wear hats, caps, bandanas when I go out because I don't want a sunburned head and I think it is more frightening to others to see a female without head hair.  I get so used to not having anything on my head while at home that sometimes I forget and go outside to get mail/newspaper without a head covering!!!!  I know one of these days, I'm going to drive off to go to the store and no cap in the car!!!! My wig I got from the American Cancer Society is sitting in a plastic ziploc bag and is probably having abandonment issues.  It is way too hot to wear and plus I'm not sure I'm a wig girl to begin with.

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2012 07:15AM Melrosemelrose wrote: lisa614- Sorry you had a rough time after the 1st round.  I had a high spiking fever 12 days after my 2nd round.  Fortunately, I called my onco asap as soon as I realized the fever wasn't going down and got two antibotics which knocked out that infection.  I did not have to go in to the ER which was a great relief to me since ER's are like a petri dish for germs to me.  My WBC was good for my 3rd round; however, after the 3d round I've had to have a Neulasta shot after each of my chemo rounds.  Glad you learned what you have to do after the chemo treatment.  I take those anti-nausea drugs are prescribed like clockwork since once you get in the nausea cycle, it isn't easy to get out of it.  As for drinking water, I have two Nalgene 32  ounce bottles that I fill and drink to make sure I get in enough water.  For some reason, the drinking out of one large bottle doesn't seem to bug me as much as drinking a bunch of individual glasses of water.  You can also drink gatorade, juice if you can tolerate it besides the water.  I also put orange slices in my water when I want to change up the taste.  Hope you are feeling better!!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 06:58AM Melrosemelrose wrote: roadwarrior28 & Other Gals Dealing With the Hair Changes- Sounds like your hair follicles are letting you know that they will be releasing the hair soon.  My head felt better once the hair started falling out and when I took showers.  I know that you are heading into the part which is not easy to handle because it is when one can visually see and physically hold the hair that has come out.  It was a yikes moment for me but I had decided not to get too freaked out and just deal with it by doing what I could do.  Yes, there was hair in the shower drain and hair everywhere on me, my clothes and my pillow.  I just cleaned, vacuumed, lint rollered the hair away and moved forward with hats/scarves/Buffs/bandanas/topless wherever and whenever comfortable.  I had a short short boy hair cut at my 2nd round and never shaved/buzzed my head.  I still some, not much of my pre-chemo hair, mainly along my hair line.   At some point around my 4th round of chemo, I started feeling a little new hair growth--- a few stubbies and peach fuzz.  I'm heading into my #6 and final chemo this coming Tuesday with more stubbies and more peach fuzz.  Yes, I rub my head to check to see if that new growth will fall out to every chance I get and to see if the rest of my pre-chemo hair is gone.    Where my eyebrows fell out, I can already see new growth.  I know it isn't easy; in fact, it is tough emotionally since now you are reminded again physically of where you are at on this journey.  No matter what, all of you are beautiful--- not just because of the physical changes but now you and the rest of the world can see what a beautiful person you have always been--- now just a little more stronger in every way!!! Have a wonderful weekend and minimal side effects!!!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 07:11AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Suzilla- Biotene also makes a dry mouth gum that will help keep your mouth moist.  You can buy it at Walgreens.  The sore jaw could be joint pain from the chemo or it could be that you are clenching you jaw at night and not know it.  If you are clenching your jaw at night, you can get a night time mouth guard.  I have TMJ and know how painful jaw pain can be.  I used to wear a dentist made mouth guard to help with that.  I also used to take Motrin for the pain and applied warm compresses to that jaw area.  You may want to try eating soft foods for a little while to help minimize the pain.    Chemo can be a very stressful time.  You may want to talk to your onco about the jaw pain.  Hope you feel better soon!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2017 12:27PM Melrosemelrose wrote: amyazing- Take a few deep breaths and know that you are not alone here. Yes, you may feel like you are on an emotional roller coaster right now.... one moment feeling okay and then another moment feeling overwhelmed, angry, tearful and just plain scared. Please try to be easy on yourself and not be angry at yourself. Do yourself a big favor and do not consult with Dr. Google. There is a lot of information out there on the internet that may be out of date or inaccurate or not applicable to your situation. Try to stick to the facts about you and your situation. Once you have a treatment plan, things will start to fall into place and hopefully help you find the calm and peace that you need right now. Do not hesitate to ask your doctors for anti-anxiety medications. If you feel you need them, ask for them. Give yourself breaks from the situation by distracting yourself. Read a magazine, watch tv, go to the movies, go shopping----anything that allows you moments of calm. Remember that you are not alone. You have the support of your husband and those here. Sending you hugs and encouragement. If you want to private message me, please feel free to do so.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2012 01:00PM - edited Oct 2, 2012 03:20PM by Melrosemelrose Caylee- Hope you have been able to take a few deep breaths to help calm yourself.  Those who have already been through chemo will tell you that most people do get anxious before the first chemo.  It is the fear of not knowing how one will react to the chemo and what to do if one does get side effects.  Hopefully, you have access to a chemo class to inform you of what to expect and enable you to ask questions.  In the event you aren't attending a pre-chemo class, then make sure you post your questions here or on the October 2012 chemo thread.  You can always private message me if you need a little help. Here is the link for Chemo info for newbies thread which is a great place to start get some helpful tips about getting through chemo, a shopping list for things to have on hand at home, wigs, and port info.   http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/785189?page=1#idx_1 You may want to read up on your chemo regimen by going to the BCO main website and looking up the individual chemo drugs that you will be infused with.  Here is the link for the chemo section: http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/chemotherapy/ For additional info on the chemo drugs and side effects, you can also go to chemocare.com which is website founded by Scott Hamilton, the former Olympic ice skater and cancer survivor link: http://www.chemocare.com/ .  The Oncolink website (Abramson Cancer Center of the University of Pennsylvania) is also helpful- http://www.oncolink.org/index_ie.cfm I was given a copy of the cookbook, Eating Well Through Cancer by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello, MD by the hospital cancer center where I'm being treated.  This book was a great help to me since it explained what I should eat the days leading up to chemo, what to eat after chemo, what to eat if I had certain side effects and shopping lists/pantry lists.  It just helped having something readily available to me and didn't require me to log on to the computer and search for some quick help.  I also bought a cookbook, the Cancer Fighting Kitchen by Rebecca Katz which has some great recipes and pictures. Wishing you the best of luck!!!!  Just keep coming back to the chemo boards for support and help.  Hugs to you!!!
Posts.Title: Scared about Chemo!! Caylee SelenaWolf

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 07:49AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Caylee - The pre-chemo prescription drugs are determined by your onco.  Some take these prescription drugs prior to the first round of chemo and some do not.   These drugs can be a steroid, anti-nausea meds and anti-anxiety meds.   You can always call your onco to find out what prescriptions you will be receiving. As for the OTC medications to have on hand for constipation, diarrhea, dry mouth, etc., that is your choice.  The shopping list for chemo newbies is helpful but you don't have to purchase everything on that list.  The list is to help you get organized and also helps you think about how to handle some of the chemo side effects.  I did purchase a lot of the items on that list but it also turned out that I didn't need most of them.  I felt like I wanted to have them on hand in the event I needed them rather than run to the drug store in a panic.  I also kept those items in a separate bin so I and my family would know where those items were.   I did make sure I purchased an extra thermometer and placed it in that bin since for some reason those things seem to disappear at my house. Just like your onco said, please try to refrain from getting info from Dr. Google.  There are some good sites out there for info (like this one) and then there are others not so good with not so current information.  As for being triple positive, it means that one can have in addition to chemo and radiation,  hormone therapy (ie Tamoxifen, Arimidex) and targeted therapy (ie Herceptin).  You read more on these therapies in the treatment section of BCO.org- here's the link: http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/ I know it isn't easy to stay calm and not to get anxious about the upcoming chemotherapy.  If you are feeling really anxious and having trouble sleeping/eating, do not hesitate to call your onco to get some medication to help you.  You do have plenty of time to get prepared for chemo and for your next appointment with your onco.  You may want to write down questions to ask your onco at the next appointment so you won't forget to ask them.  By the way, what chemo regimen are you having?
Posts.Title: Scared about Chemo!! Caylee SelenaWolf

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 11:02AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Caylee- As you will learn, there are no absolute guarantees here.  One has to view available treatments that one can take as a part of the arsenal of weapons/tools to treat cancer. Sounds like you are having Taxotere/Carboplatin/Herceptin-- TCH regimen.  The Taxotere/Carbonplatin is the chemotherapy  and the Herceptin is the hormone therapy.  You may want to visit that thread in the Chemotherapy Forum as well as the October 2012 Chemo thread to get support.  Glad to hear that you are getting a pre-chemo steroid.  I took Decadron for three days, twice a day starting the day before my chemo.  Decadron has tendency to get one wired which makes sleeping at night difficult.  I took my Decadron in the morning with breakfast at 7 am and took it with dinner no later than 7 pm.  You want to make sure you take the steroid with food because the steroid can by itself make one become nauseous. Decadron is an anti-nausea med so it will be in your system before you have the chemo round. Not everyone has a port put in.  If you want one, you may ask your onco if you can have one installed.  The Herceptin infusions are for one year and will continue after you finish chemo.  (I'm glad I have a port because my veins just bury themselves when they hear nurses coming!!) Hope you have calmed down a little.  HUGS!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2015 08:58AM - edited Jan 10, 2015 09:00AM by Melrosemelrose Bmpntherd- Hang in there !!!! I fortunately was given two cook books that helped me through the 6 rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere. The first book is Eating Well through Cancer by Gerald Miletello, MD and Holly Clegg and the second book is The Cancer Fighting Kitchen by Rebecca Katz. The first book has meal plans, recipes, shopping lists and helpful tips as to how to handle certain side effects; the second book had great pictures and recipes and helpful tips. I ate 5-6 small meals and tried to eat for nutritional purposes rather than for comfort. I ate rather bland meals the first two weeks after chemo. A few days after chemo, my taste buds would go on vacation and thankfully returned the beginning of week 3. I kept a food diary which helped keep me on track and also record what foods I handled the best when. I also found out that I could not tolerate butter and salt during chemo. Just didn't like the taste or feel in my mouth. I hope your favorite foods remain your favorite foods once you finish chemo. I am lucky that I gained very little weight during chemo and my taste buds returned with no problem. Wishing you the best!!!!!

Posts.Content: May 19, 2014 01:21PM - edited May 19, 2014 01:23PM by Melrosemelrose Keep breathing, SweetMaggie...... keep on taking those deep calming breaths!  Yes, it definitely a time when you are being bombarded with information and what if's.  I know that you will feel a little more at ease once you know your treatment plan and where you are heading.  I also know that hurry up and wait feeling you may have.  Your situation will reveal itself all in due time.  Hopefully, patience will become your friend as it became mine.  For the time being, try to stay off Dr. Google.  Dr. Google is not nice.  Sometimes the information is outdated, inaccurate and just may not apply to your situation.  Instead, focus on your case.... on your facts and your test results.  It would be a good idea to check out the BCO.org main website Treatment Section.  You will find info and a list of questions to ask your surgeon.  If you have questions, write them down and take them with you to your next appointment.  If you can, have a significant other or good friend or spouse go with you to your appointment.  It is so good to have some emotional support at this initial appointments plus another set of ears to hear what is being said to you.  I can recall there were times that I know I could see the doctor's lips moving, sounds were coming out but my brain couldn't comprehend a thing.  It's okay to ask questions at these appointment and to ask the explanations to be repeated.  If you are feeling anxious, you can definitely ask for some anti-anxiety meds.  If you have a chance, get a month to month calendar so you can keep track of your appointments, tests, etc.  You may also want to prepare a list of phone numbers of doctors, 24 hour pharmacy nearby, emergency numbers to take with you to your appointments.  Also a list of allergies to meds, foods, etc is handy as well as a list of previous surgeries.  I know at these appointments/tests, there are always forms to fill out.  It is so much easier to have that info ready to go so you don't have to search for it when you are trying to fill out the forms.  So...... get ready for that emotional roller coaster that you have boarded...... fasten that seat belt and hold on tight..... we will ride the roller coaster together..... scream our heads off, laugh, cry and always remembering that you are not alone.   Wishing you the best and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2012 04:12PM Melrosemelrose wrote: You may be sore for at least a week after the port placement.  I had my port placed during my UMX surgery.  My BS told me before the UMX surgery that the port area would probably hurt/be sore more than the UMX.  He was so right!!!!  Check with your onco to see if you can take some over the counter pain reliever (ie Advil/Motrin/Tylenol) to help with the pain/soreness.  It does get better. I hope you asked the onco to prescribe some EMLA cream (lidocaine cream) that you can apply an hour before you go in for a round of chemo.  The EMLA cream will help numb the area so you won't feel the poke.  Most likely, you will need to wait to use the EMLA cream after the port suture has healed a little since EMLA cream can't be used on newly sutured skin.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2012 08:46AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Cadillac- Hope all goes well with your family friend.  It will be helpful for you to go the the main section of BCO and read about the Node Biopsy. what to expect after surgery, chemotherapy, hormone target therapy and radiation therapy.  It will help you have a basic understanding and knowledge of what is happening. Drains- Drains are one of those necessary post surgical things that people find troublesome.  Before your friend is discharged from the hospital, make sure she is given written instructions for "stripping the drain line" and how to care for the drain and that she is shown how to care for the drain.  It is not a difficult process and very doable.  Usually, the drain needs to be emptied several times a day and the amounts recorded in the log.  This info will help the surgeon determine when the drain should be removed.  One of the most discussed things about drains is a drain holder.  One can use different things as a drain holder -- the drain can be safety pinned to clothing, the drain can be placed in a fanny pack or small purse with a long strap, an id neck cord or purchase a special drain holder or camisole with removable drain holders.  I opted to purchase from Target for $29.99 front zip Champion athletic jackets that had inside pockets.  Lymph Node Biopsy- You won't know the extent of that procedure until the surgeon removes and examines the nodes during the surgery.  Like Chrissy said, one is sore after that. Post Op care - I would think how much attention your friend will need post surgery will be dependent upon how long she stays in the hospital and the extent of her surgery.  I know that I was instructed as well as given written instructions on how to care for myself after I was released from the hospital.  I also asked a lot of questions of the nurses and surgeon as to what I should do and did not wait for someone to tell me.  One should also be mindful of other post op side effects such as constipation, nausea and diarrhea.  I avoided constipation problems by drinking prune juice/apple juice and eating Sunsweet Ones individually packaged prunes.  As for nausea, I was given a motion sickness patch behind my ear when I was being prepped for surgery.  I did not experience any nausea post op. Chemo & Radiation - I get the feeling you want to prepare yourself and your wife as to how to care for your friend as she moves forward with her treatment plan.  Read the BCO main sections first and as your friend continues to heal and approach each new phase of the treatment, she/you should visit the individual forums (Chemotherapy/Radiation) so all can learn from the personal experiences of others and also get great support. Herceptin- I'd read the BCO section on Herceptin so you will understand that being HER2+ means a patient has one more weapon in her arsenal to fight cancer.  I'm currently in a Herceptin clinical trial and would not be receiving Herceptin as a standard chemo protocal but for this trial. Wishing you all the best of luck and glad to know there are such wonderful and kind people willing to help a friend in need.  Positive healing and calming prayers, thoughts and energy!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 12:36PM Melrosemelrose wrote: So very sorry to hear about your mom.  It is wise that both of you try to limit your research since playing Dr. Google tends to be not a good thing.  You are at a good site that has great information and support.  So as things progress, please keep coming back to get information and support.  Perhaps, later on, your Mom will want to get on here herself so she can get that great support whenever she needs it. As for what to ask the surgeon, here is a link to the main BCO website "Questions To Ask Your Surgeon About Mastectomy:  http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/surgery/mastectomy/questions.  The BCO.org website is a good source of information to help answer a lot of your questions that you may have. As to order of physicians, it is personal choice.  My oncologist led the way for my mastectomy and everything else (chemo/the no rads decision).  She is the one who recommended the second breast surgeon I had since that breast surgeon was more experienced than the first and one that she works with on a regular basis.  The second breast surgeon only does breast surgeries whereas the first one I had did other types of surgeries.  At the time I met with my oncologist, the pathology report of my lumpectomy was not totally in but enough was in that she knew what my tentative treatment plan would be.   If you feel more comfortable seeing an oncologist first, then do so.  As for the pathology report, those identifiers will be revealed once what is removed is analyzed and examined by the pathologist.  The breast surgeon removes the cancer and the pathologist analyzes what is removed. As for not having a recent mammogram.... try not to focus on what she hasn't done but simply what she is now doing.  We can't go back and look at the what-if's and just really need to focus in a positive way about moving forward.  The oncologist may order additional tests such as a PET scan, CT scan to help determine if there are other places in the body that the cancer may be.  These tests will help give the oncologist more information in formulating your Mom's treatment plan. Sending you and your Mom and your family, lots of HUGS and positive calming and healing prayers, thoughts and energy.  I know there will be times of emotional ups and downs ahead and patience may be hard to find at times.  It is one day at a time, one step at a time.......

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2012 08:08PM Melrosemelrose wrote: I had six rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere.  I started to lose some eyebrows/eyelashes after the 4th round.  After the last round (#6), my eyebrows and bottom eyelashes were gone but sometime during Week-week 6 PFC, the eyebrows and eyelashes came back.  My head hair started to fall out 14 days after my first round.  I'm almost 4 months PFC and my head hair looks like a very short short boy cut.  As for the nails,  I iced the fingers and toes for all 6 rounds of chemo.  No neuropathy and the nails have minimal damage. On each finger nail, I have 6 horizontal "dents" which coincide with the number of chemo rounds I had and some faint longitudinal finger nail discoloration on my thumb nail.  I also used Essie All In One Top Coat on my nails although my onco suggested using Sally Hansen Hard as Nails Clear nail polish.  The Essie brand seemed to stay on longer than the Sally Hansen brand.  If your onco/infusion center doesn't object to your icing, you may still want to ice even though the nurse said your nails would be fine.  It's a personal choice as to whether you want to ice or not since no one can predict how your body will react to the chemo.  If you want some tips for icing, let me know.  I can private message you some info so you don't have to search on all of the chemo threads to find out the info.  Wishing you the best.....
Posts.Title: Cytoxine and Taxotere, 4 rounds...your thoughts? Nanc620 bahamamom3

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2012 07:00AM Melrosemelrose wrote: beachmd-  i iced for all 6 rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere.  As for the hands, I wore these knitted gauntlets that left my fingers and thumbs uncovered.  If I didn't have those, i was going to use some fingerless gloves.  I know that you can get a set of knitted gloves from Target that have  a pair of regular gloves and a set of fingerless gloves you can wear over the regular gloves.  The set is about $3.00.  You can just wear the fingerless gloves by themselves.  As for the socks, I did wear thin athletic socks so that the ice would not be directly on my toes.  To help keep the ice in place, I put the small ice bags in Neoprene (it's what scuba suits are made of) wine bags that I purchased at Target for $7.00 each.  Those wine bags kept the ice in place and allowed me to position the ice where I wanted.  I brought ice from home rather than use the ice from the infusion center because it didn't melt as fast as the ice chips would. I had a prescription for Latisse but never filled it.  My bottom eyelashes and eyebrows started to fall out around round 4 and were gone right after round 6.  They did grow back within 4 weeks after round 6.  Lashes and brows can fall out after one finishes all of the chemo and may fall out several times during the first year.  The lashes and brows are on a different growth cycle than the head hair is.  I've read that some use the Latisse throughout the chemo and some have waited until finishing chemo.  You may want to ask your onco what he/she thinks.   I didn't use the cold caps and just let my hair go.  I wanted to see exactly what the chemo was going to do to my hair.  It didn't all fall out; I was left a very thin veil of hair.  At 4 months PFC, I now have a very short short boy hair cut.  Some people have even asked me where I had my hair cut.... lol.  I tell them I had the most expensive hair cut and skin exfoiliation treatment that I've ever had!!!! Wishing you the best and always post if you have more questions.  You can even private message me if you want.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 11:44AM Melrosemelrose wrote: I iced for all 6 round of Cytoxan/Taxotere.  Here are some instructions I wrote a while ago if you want to know how to do the icing.  Private message if you have further questions..... FOR THOSE ICING NAILS DURING TAXOTERE INFUSION: Always clear anything you want to do with your oncos.  You will need to clear it with your onco about icing since not all oncos will allow icing during the Taxotere infusion.  At the suggestion of my onco, I am using clear nail polish on my nails to help keep them strong and also icing the nails to help prevent nail damage which is a side effect of Taxotere.  She suggested that use Sally Hansen Strong As Nails Clear Polish but I switched to Essie polish since it doesn't chip as much as the Sally Hansen brand.  Essie polish costs more but for someone like me who never used nail polish before chemo, the fewer times I have to apply polish the better.  I don't mani/pedis but some do.  I'd rather avoid the germ issue at nail salons and taking of a chance of getting nicked.  ICING : Process- I let the infusion nurse know that i'm icing so we can coordinate when I should start the icing. Once I know when I'm going to start the infusion, I put the ice bags in the bottom of the Neoprene bags.  I put the ones on my feet first and adjust the ice bags so my toes nails are covered.  I then put the ones on my hands on and adjust the ice to cover my fingernails.  My husband helps me with this process. GOOD  LUCK!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2012 08:09PM Melrosemelrose wrote: A/C every two weeks is known as dense dose.  My understanding is that one's WBC is monitered closely to make sure it is safe to have this chemo regimen every two weeks.  The oncologist may prescribe Neulasta or Neuprogen shots to help the WBC counts between the chemo rounds.  The following info is from chemocare.com website ( website founded by Scott Hamilton, the ice skater and cancer survivor).  Hope this info helps. Here is the link for that info: http://www.chemocare.com/bio/adriamycin.asp & http://www.chemocare.com/bio/cytoxan.asp The following side effects are common (occurring in greater than 30%) for patients taking adriamycin: Early: (within one week after treatment begins) Later: (within two weeks after treatment begins) The following side effects are less common (occurring in 10-29%) for patients taking adriamycin: Early: (within one week after treatment begins) Later: (within two weeks after treatment begins) A serious but uncommon side effect of adriamycin can be interference with the pumping action of the heart.  You can receive only up to a certain amount of adriamycin during your lifetime.  This "lifetime maximum dose" may be lower if you have heart disease risk factors such as radiation to the chest, advancing age, and use of other heart-toxic drugs.  Your doctor will check your heart function before you may take any adriamycin and will monitor your heart closely during your treatment.  Dose-related heart problems can occur as late as 7 or 8 years after treatments have ended. ********************************* The following side effects are common (occurring in greater than 30%) for patients taking Cytoxan:

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2012 08:08AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Linda2222- Take a few deep breaths.  I know you are overwhelmed by all of the recent events and things are coming at you faster than you can comprehend.  This is an emotional roller coaster you are on; however, you are not alone and have lots of support surrounding you.  If you feel you need counseling now, get it.  Don't wait!!!  If there is counseling available at the cancer center/hospital that you are being treated, make an appointment.  You may talk to your breast surgeon/oncologist to get counseling.  The American Cancer Society in your area has counseling services also.  In short, get the support you need since there isn't really any right time or wrong time to get it.  I don't know if they have an oncology nurse navigator at your treatment facility.  If they do, make an appointment with them and they may be able to provide you with a wealth of information and a little comfort as to how to go about getting info and things you need during treatment. Information as to your case will come all in due time.  The more facts about your case through testing will help your medical team determine the best treatment plan tailored for you.  I know the time before each test/scan is frightening but take comfort in knowing you can do this and will get through this time.  It will be a hurry and wait situation as you get your tests.  If you need meds to help keep you calm, then get them and take them.  No sign of weakness for asking for help and saying out loud that you are scared and frightened.  Patience will become your friend as it has become mine since I heard those brain numbing words this past February 2012. Take one step at a time, one day at time.  There is a lot of information out there about breast cancer so please do not "Dr. Google".   You'll find that it is necessary at times to self edit when reading things and so click away.   Learn the information in steps and not the entire world of breast cancer.  It is just too much to comprehend all at once.    Once you know your treatment plan, you can focus one the part of the treatment plan that is right in front of you.  You'll be able to educate yourself on that phase and move forward to the next one.  Wishing you the best.  Sending you HUGS, positive calming and healing prayers, thoughts and energy.  As always, trying to find a little peace, a little calm, lots of good conversation, smiles and laughter and moving forward....

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 08:31PM Melrosemelrose wrote: If your mom is still in a lot of pain, you may want to call the oncologist on call and ask what to do.   My onco had prescribed Zantac or Pepcid when I had some stomach discomfort with my first round of chemo.  I didn't take any though because the stomach discomfort was minimal.  You may also want to monitor her diet since maybe the food she is eating may be causing some of the discomfort.  If she is not eating enough food, her stomach could also be upset.  Again, the best thing to do is call the onco this weekend and discuss with the doctor what she is eating, how often she eats, the frequency of the stomach growling, and the intensity of the pain.  Sorry there isn't some magic answer of how to resolve this tonight.  Keep us posted and hope she feels better.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2018 06:12PM Melrosemelrose wrote: My oncologist told me that i would receive Neulasta shots if and when it became necessary. Ten days after my 2nd round of chemo, I developed a high fever and chills. As I recall, the fever and chills started on a Sunday. My husband called my oncologist who ordered antibiotics for me which allowed me to avoid a emergency room visit. The antibiotics did worked and I was able to have my 3rd round of chemo on the scheduled date, the following week. I started receiving a Neulasta shot the day after my 3rd round of Cytoxan/Taxotere and continued to receive them after rounds 4-6. The onset of the high fever and chills did occur during the nadir period which is the considered the lowest point that a chemo patient cell count reaches after receiving a round of chemo. That one incidence of fever and chills was the only incidence of fever and chills I experienced after a chemo round. Blood lab work was done the day of chemo so I was always knew what my counts were before I had the chemo round. Wishing you the best with the rest of your chemo rounds!!!!

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2012 12:00AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Oh Suzilla.... hugs and take some deep calming breaths....... 1.  You don't have to write a will out if you don't want to.  Since I don't know what state you live in, a written will does let everyone know your wishes and intent for things that may be valuable/significant to you.  If you are talking about a living will/ directives to physicians... it helps let everyone know what you want when you are unable to speak for yourself.  You may be able to contact a legal aid clinic in the city that you live to help answer your questions in more detail. 2.  Since I only had a UMX, I can't tell you how one feels after a BMX.  I can tell you that with my UMX, I did not feel much pain.  The reason being that I made sure I took my pain meds on schedule whether I was in pain or not.  It is easier to stay ahead of the pain by taking the meds like that.  As for your arm motion, you will have limited motion initially.  You will need to give yourself time to heal and not be impatient.  You will work up to more arm movement. 3.  Yes.... you can ask your BS for a referral to a physical therapist.  You can ask the BS for the referral when you go have one of your post surgery follow up visits. 4.  Yes.... ask for a motion sickness patch in the pre-op room from the anesthesiaologist.  I had one behind my ear before my UMX surgery and did not have any post-op nausea for the anesthesia. 5.  Can't tell you how long your surgery will last.  You need to ask the BS.  Your hospital stay is dependent upon the BS and your insurance.  For my UMX, I stayed 3 days.  6.  Understandably, you may be anxious about the surgery.  It's pretty normal. 7.  If you go to the Surgery Thread, you will find a thread with the shopping list  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/91/topic/699896?page=20#idx_598 I know it is a lot to read but I think you find some helpful information.  Post surgery clothes- button down shirts that are easy to get into (men's shirts work well), athletic warm up pants with elastic that are easy to get on and off, nothing that you pull over your head-- you need to be able to step into camisoles, etc.  You can order a post op camisole from the TLC Catalogue http://www.tlcdirect.org/.  You can also get a masectomy camisole from a women's specialty medical store if there is one in your area.  There are also alternatives to purchasing a camisole--- lanyards, fanny pack, front zip athletic jackets with inside pockets, just safety pinning the drains to your blouse/shirt, drain belt, drain vest.....  You may want to purchase a wedge pillow or at least have lots of bed pillows to help you sleep.  Some sleep in recliners post surgery at home and some even rent hospital beds. 8. Go to the BCO.org section on Radiation http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/radiation to read up on rads. It is fine to read/educate yourself on the next phase of treatment but again try not to overwhelm yourself.  It is one step at a time; one day at a time.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2014 11:09AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Take a deep breathe..... you are on track with the hair growth.  Yes, I did have that soft downy duck fuzz.... very white.... almost clear in color and hard to see.   I know that the very tips of my hair are extremely thin in comparison to the rest of the hair shaft so I know what you are saying about the fineness that your hair is right now.   I could feel it every time i rubbed my head; I felt like a Velveteen Rabbit stuffed animal.  I even used some silly putty to see if I could make an impression of my head/hair to see if there was really hair.  Of course, I couldn't see anything on the silly putty... lol.  I did not shave my head and slowly but surely, my hair has returned.  In fact, the last time I had a hair cut was May 2012 ( I gave myself a short boy haircut).  I haven't cut it since it looks like a layered hair cut with the longest hair below my shoulders.  I had a different chemo regimen than you (Cytoxan/Taxotere) and feel fortunate that my hair has returned evenly and to the original color.  I use Nioxin shampoo and hair conditioner which I can't say for sure that it is helping.  I really like how the shampoo smells more than anything else.  You may want to try taking some Biotin to help with the hair growth.  I know some take that supplement to help.  I also know that I did some research on what foods to eat to help with hair growth.  Just put in a search like that on the livestrong.com website if you are interested in the dietary aspect of hair growth.  It does take a little while for those hair follicles to wake up and realize that you are not having chemo anymore.  Wishing you the best and hoping your might hair makes its return so that you can see it.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2018 11:28AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Wildcolonialgirl- Here is a link to the Step Up Speak Out Lymphedema website which may provide you more information about LE. http://www.stepup-speakout.org When flying, I wear a sleeve and a hand gauntlet and make an effort to exercise my arm during the flight. I use hand squeeze ball and do a series of arm exercises/flexing. There is some discussion about whether to wear a hand glove or gauntlet when wearing a sleeve on the Step Up Speak Out Organization website. The rationale for wearing the hand gauntlet with the sleeve is to help prevent the possible fluid buildup in the hand/fingers that may occur from wearing only a sleeve. As you will discover, deciding whether to wear a sleeve/hand gauntlet/hand glove is very personal choice. Safe travels.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 08:31AM Melrosemelrose wrote: I started losing a few eyebrows at the 4th round.  By the 6th round, more had left.  A few weeks after my final #6 chemo, I had very few left.  However, once my body figured out that there wasn't any more chemo, they grew back very fast.  I'm fortunate that they came back fuller than they were before I had chemo and never have fallen out again.  I have read in several places that the eyebrows and eyelashes can fall out several times during the first year of being PFC.  This is because the eyebrows and eyelashes are on a different growth cycle than the head hair.  It takes time for the eyebrow and eyelash hair follicles to get back in sync and return to normal.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 09:01AM Melrosemelrose wrote: After one of my initial meetings with my oncologist, I knew before I had any surgery that I would be having the additional testing after surgery and before any additional treatment (chemo/rads)Within 10 days of my UMX surgery, the hosptial was already calling schedule a bone scan and CT scan. I felt so rushed and wasn't sure the oncologist was listening to me when I let her know that I was possibly allergic to the dyes used in the bone scan and CT scan.  I voiced my concerns and made sure my medical team(BS surgeon, oncologist) heard me and I got the time I needed.   Everyone agreed that I was in control of when the tests would be and futher treatment would occur.   I did ask the BS if he foresaw any reasons why I couldn't have the scans post-surgery, and he told me I would be fine.  I had the PET/CT scan the week before I started my chemo.  Nothing was found on the PET/CT Scan.  I can tell you that the PET/CT scan is expensive and it took a phone call from my oncologist to get the insurance company to approve it after initially denying coverage.  When I spoke to the hospital scheduling the scan, I asked for the price.  I was told two prices--- list price $7500 and cash price $4400.  I know the PET/CT scan costs more than the bone scan and contrast dye CT Scan.  I don't know if this helps you.

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2013 11:38AM Melrosemelrose wrote: As you are finding out, this fact gathering-investigative phase is not easy to deal with.  Yes, it means you are in the "hurry up and wait" mode which is is hard on one's emotions.  As your situation continues to reveal itself through testing/scans, a plan of action will begin to formulate.  Believe it or not, you do have a part of plan now--- it is the testing and investigating step.  Again, try not to get ahead of the situation because you may find yourself overwhelmed with everything.  One day at a time; one step at a time.  I know your patience may be wearing thin but you will learn that Patience will become your best friend.  Remember, no Dr. Google because what you find may not apply to your situation.  As for the waiting, one's mind does start to wander to places that are not easy to deal with.  Try to stay busy and distracted and give yourself a break.  Take time to do other things like walking, watching mindless tv, shopping, etc.--- anything to give yourself a 5 minute, 10 minute, 30 minutes and hour break.  You still need to eat healthy, get plenty of rest and exercise which are positive ways for you to help yourself. What Leaf said to you is true.  One does always want to know what the possibilities are if the diagnosis is breast cancer.  If it is, you can educate yourself with just enough knowledge so you know what would happen.  However, just a word of caution that you don't go too far and get too ahead of yourself.  What does this mean... if you want to read up on  breast cancer and treatments in general, go to BCO.org main website and read up there.    You will find good information and questions to ask your doctors.   Once you and your doctors know more information about your situation and a plan of treatment is formulated, then you will feel a little calmer about things. Hang in there and again, give yourself a mind break this weekend.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 08:05AM Melrosemelrose wrote: I did what Momof3boys did, cut it short around chemo time and no more haircuts/buzzing/shaving after that. I had waist length hair at the time of my initial diagnosis in Feb 2012; then a short bob at the time of my UMX in March 2012 and a very short short boy cut May 2012.  The short boy cut was 1 inch in length around the back and sides and the front was left longer.  My husband and I cut the short boy cut at home because I got annoyed with the hair falling out everywhere right before my 2nd round of chemo.  That hair was liberating and empowering since I felt I was in control and cut part of the hair myself.  I made 5 little ponytails and snipped them off myself and had my husband use his trusty electric clippers with a 1 inch guard to clean up the sides and back.  It was my personal science experiment throughout chemo to see if all of my hair would fall out from the chemo.  To my surprise, it did not all fall out.  I am 7 weeks PFC and still have some (not many) pre-chemo hair.  I'm glad that I did not buzz/shave my head since I felt I had already gone through enough major hair cuts in 3 months time.  Most of the hair that stayed was along my hairline which allowed me to have some "wispy" bangs and back neck nape hair to show when I wore bandanas.  For some unknown reason, still having the pre-chemo hair hang on made me feel better and I could look at the hair in the mirror and not focus on the fact that the rest of it was gone.  I know it is very personal choice as to what to do.  There are no written rules as to what one should.  You need to feel comfortable with yourself and do what is right for you.  No matter what you decide to do, you are still beautiful!!!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 10:03PM Melrosemelrose wrote: FOR THOSE GETTING A NEULASTA SHOT AFTER YOUR ROUND OF CHEMO:  You may want to try taking regular 24 hour Claritin to help with the bone pain that may accompany the Neulasta shot.  There is an ongoing clinical trial evaluating Claritin to prevent the bone pain.  Here is the link:  (clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NC...) According to the clinical trial, one takes the Claritin (10 mg) once a day for 7 days beginning the day of the Neulasta treatment. I had my first Neulasta shot with my 3rd round of Cytoxan/Taxotere and took the Claritin.  I did not experience any bone pain.  The Claritin doesn't help everyone but it is worth a try since from my understanding the bone pain may be intense.  Just remember to ask your onco about trying the Claritin before you take it. Also, I am curious as to whether you know about icing your nails to help prevent nail damage from the chemo.  If you aren't, let me know and I can post some info for you as to how to do this.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2013 09:26AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Lmimp64- Wishing you the best on Wednesday!!! Here is my hair story:   I cut my waist length hair to a short bob for my UMX at a Supercuts; I personally cut with the help of my husband to a short short boy cut 2 weeks after I had my first round of chemo.  My hair started falling out and I got very annoyed with the hair being everywhere ( on me, my clothes, my pillowcase, etc).  I used a lint roller to pick up all of that hair but did not use the lint roller on my head.  I made 8 little pony tails and snipped them off myself.  It was a very liberating experience since I felt like I was in control of my hair.  I never cut/shaved/buzzed after that and just waited to see what my hair would do.  I did have a very thin veil of hair remain at the end of round 6.  I never wore a wig but had received one through the American Cancer Society's Look Good Feel Good program.  I wore hats, bandanas, Buffs or knitted caps.  I found hats at Target, Charming Charlie's, Marshalls, TJ Maxx.  I did try them on at the store and I did not let the fact that I had very little hair bother me when I was trying them on.  I know it isn't easy to go out in public and think that people are looking at you while you try on the hats.  My son is the one who helped me get past feeling awkward when I had sparse hair.  He told me that those people are strangers and not friends of mine and I would probably never see them again.  In short, the absence of hair just didn't matter and that I was still who I was before the hair loss.  You never know what is going to come out of the mouth of an 18 year old!!!  The physical changes and tranformations that one goes through is not easy but always decide what is best for you.  Good luck in the BGC aka the Big Girl Chair !!!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2012 05:26PM Melrosemelrose wrote: cutiegirl- Make sure you make a new batch of the 1/4 teaspoon baking soda + 1/4 teaspoon salt + 1 cup of warm water solution every time you rinse.   It may take a few days to work.  You may also want to easy when you are brushing your teeth so not to irritate things.  You may also want to have several toothbrushes on hand so you are using a "clean" toothbrush.  You can clean toothbrushes by putting them in the dishwasher.  I have a toothbrush sanitizer that I purchased at Marshall/TJ Maxx.  Like dlb823, join the August 2012 chemo group for help and support.  You can also jump in on one of the Cytoxan/Taxotere threads too!!!!  (PS--I also hang out on those threads from time to time)  Hope you feel better soon!!!!!

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 08:56AM Melrosemelrose wrote: lmmclure- Just want to let you know that you can get out of the house and do things; however be a little cautious when you do.  This means you need to know when your nadir period with your chemo regimen is so that you don't venture out when you know your white blood count is at its lowest.  Since it is also the flu season, you do want to be careful to avoid large crowds of people to minimize your exposure to other people.  I ventured out  frequently when I was on chemo.  I went shopping (grocery stores, mall, Target, bookstore, etc.) and also went out to eat.  With that being said, I tried to avoid those people (adults/children) who were coughing and sneezing and with runny noses.   I did not go to any movies or try to shop or go places where I knew that there would be a lot of people in places in small physical spaces  ( ie small coffee shop, small stores).  I know it isn't easy to be cooped up in a house with small children 24/7 but you can get out as long as you are cautious and aware of your surroundings.    As for seeing people that you know while out, the tendency is for them to want to hug you or shake your hand.  The better thing to do is to avoid the hug/handshake and instead give elbow bumps or fist/knuckle bumps with a little provisio that you are having chemo.  Make sure you wash your hands and carry hand sanitizer when you are out and about. Take care of yourself and try not to be super duper Super Woman/Mom while on chemo.  Yes, you can be Super Woman/Mom but your body will let you know that you have done too much if you try to do everything yourself.  Don't hesitate to ask for help from family and friends.  Continue to eat well and rest whenever you can.  After the first round of chemo, you will have an idea of how you may feel after each round of chemo.  Wishing you the best with your upcoming chemo.   HUGS!!!!
