Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2013 07:18PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Take some deep calming breaths.  I know you are in a state of shock and overwhelmed by the enormity of the situation.  As you will read here, the initial days/weeks of diagnosis is like being on an emotional roller coaster--- one moment you think you can handle everything and the next moment, you are so frightened and scared and just can't seem to get a grip on everything.  I recall the moment when the radiologist told me that he wasn't exactly sure what he found but whatever it was needed to come out as soon as possible.  The words sounded so surreal and there was a deafening clarity in the air that I had never heard before.  The biopsy as well as other tests will bring more factual information so that a treatment plan can be formulated for you by your doctors and you.  Patience is hard to find right now but in time, the situation will reveal itself and you will know what you are dealing with.  It is one day at a time, one step of a time here.  You will find plenty of support and help here as I and others have found; no one is ever alone here.  Many have travelled this path before you and some of us linger a little longer to help guide those who have just embarked on this adventure.  Just keep coming back here..... say what you need to say to help get you and your family through this time.  Sending many many (((HUGS))) and positive calming and healing prayers, thoughts and energy to both of you.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2018 09:40AM Melrosemelrose wrote: You may want to call her oncologist today to have a chat about her persistent nausea. The oncologist can adjust her medications. It is better not to wait and see if this will get better on its own. Some anti-nausea medications can cause nausea on their own if taken on an empty tummy and without food. Once she gets the nausea under control, she may want to try eating 5-6 small meals a day so there is always some food in her tummy. Meanwhile, call her oncologist and get some help.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2017 02:42PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Just read each of your posts and am glad that each of you have found your way here. You will find support and comfort and a place to say how you feel about where you are. Always try to remember that you are not alone.... there are many people in your own lives as well as people here to give you support and help. I know your emotional roller coaster ride has begun. Buckle in and hold on tight as you travel on this road. This phase is where it is hurry up and wait filled with doctors appointments and testing. The details and your treatment plan will be revealed to you in due time. Keep breathing. As others have said, if you feel you need some anti-anxiety meds, do not hesitate to ask. Only you can tell your medical team how you feel and what you need as you learn the facts about your medical situation. Try to take care of yourself--- eat well and rest. Each of you probably have busy households and need lots of energy and calmness to move forward. It is good to have your spouse/significant other go with you to your appointments. Sometimes one does not hear everything during this appointments. it just helps to have another set of ears to hear what the doctors are telling you and also to give you much needed support. Take a note pad with you to write down notes during your appointments. Ask for copies of your reports and test results and keep those in a file folder so you can keep track of that information. You may want to jot down questions on that note pad before you go to the appointment so you can ask the doctors any questions that have come to mind. If you don't understand something that is discussed during one of your appointments, ask the doctor to explain it until you understand. Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2012 03:28AM Melrosemelrose wrote: anamerty-  My DCIS and IDC were found togther in an encapsulated cystic structure.  When I went to see my first breast surgeon ( I later switched breast surgeons) and before I had my partial masectomy/lumpectomy, he thought it was just a large cyst.  He also did a fine needle aspiration and sent that sample to be analyzed.  The results of that sample did not indicate the finding of any cancer cells and so he presumed that it was just a large cyst.  The pathology of the cyst turned out to be otherwise.  I met with my oncologist a week after the partial masectomy b/c I didn't want to wait until the first breast surgeon returned from his vacation 10 days later.  I switched breast surgeons since I knew that I would have to additional surgery since the first surgery did not result in clean margins and went with a breast surgeon who only deals with breast cancer patients and who was recommended by my oncologist.  I had a UMX in March 2012 to get the clean margins and also had a SNL performed at that time.  In late April, I started chemo and just recently completed 6 rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere.    The Tumor Board at the hospital I'm treated at recently recommended that I did not need radiation therapy because of the no node involvement, clean margins, size of the IDC and also the fact that the cancer was encapsulated.  It has also been suggested that the pathology perfomed of the cyst after the first surgery was inadequately performed.   I read the pathology report myself and had questions in my own mind about the completeness and adequacy of the patholgy performed.  My oncologist told me that I was being treated for the most aggressive cancer-- the IDC.  I know you are anxious about what your onco has already told you.  Once you meet with your breast surgeon, you will have a much better idea of what will take place surgerywise.  I hope you will have someone with you when you have your visit with the surgeon.  If you can, make a list of questions to ask the surgeon.  I was told by my onco and second breast surgeon that having a lumpectomy + radiation would be the same as my having a masectomy.  I am small breasted. Because of the large size of the removed cyst, a masectomy was the best way and probably the only way to get clean margins.  I did not have any recon because I developed a breast infection in the left breast (the problem breast).  It was a blessing in disguise that I didn't have to make a decision about recon since at that time, I was overwhelmed with everything.  You might want to ask the surgeon about your surgical and reconstruction options and recovery period.  Sending you lots of hugs and positive, calming and healing prayers, thoughts and energy.  As everyone will tell you here, you are not alone.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 01:47AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Angiebaby1- Clothing -- That is a fun topic for me since shopping is always theraputic.  One of the things that you have probably already know about is that you will drains after your surgery.  Everyone has her personal picks for post-op wear.  You may want ask your BS what he/she will have you wearing right out of surgery.  Some BS put their patients in an ace bandage wrap while others have them in a bra.  Knowing that information helps.  I was put in a ace bandage wrap post surgery.  I purchased 2 Champion brand zip up work out jackets ($30.00) from Target that are super soft and comfy.  The reason I bought those particular jackets was because they have inside pockets which I used to hold my drains.  Each inside pocket will hold two drains.  I bought them a size larger than I normally wear because it was easier for me to get in and out of the jacket. You can go to a specialty post-op store to purchase camisoles that have removeable drain pockets and come with boob inserts.  I didn't wear mine until the BS removed the ace bandage.  Make sure that any camisole you purchase that you can step into it rather the normal head first.  Your doctor will tell you not head first clothing and you may just find that it hurts a little to put on and take off clothing that way. You can also pin those drains to any shirt/top you are wearing.  You can ask the nursing staff to give you some while you are in the hospital.  they usually pin the drains to your hospital gown. If you are allowed to take a shower after surgery ( I wasn't allowed), you can use one of those ID Badge lanyards to hold the drains. Regular clothing:  Front button down shirts are the easiest to get in and out of.  Finding them is sometimes a problem.  If you can't find any in the women's dept, go to the men's dept.  No over the head clothing during your initial recovery b/c your doctor may not allow it and you will find that it may be too painful to do so.  I usually wear athletic clothing while I'm lounging at home because they are easy to get on and off.  If you have any questions, don't hesitate to contact me.  Happy shopping!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2015 04:29AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Lori- Welcome.... there are many here to give your support through the beginning of this adventure. Keep taking deep breaths . I recognize those feelings you are having right now.... somewhat confusing..... somewhat overwhelming.... just a a lot all at once. This is the emotional roller coaster ride one gets on here.... so tighten that seat belt and hold on and scream and yell and laugh while we ride this ride together. Glad you found this website and posted. I know you probably thought as I did, what the heck and how did I end up here. There are no real answers for some events in our lives..... just that things happen and we just have to try to do our best. As for deciding what surgery to have, that is such a personal decision and not an easy one to make. I consulted with 2 breast surgeons and an oncologist before my unilateral mastectomy ( UMX) and was told the same thing..a UMX best for me and that I didn't need to have my healthy breast removed. I had a lumpectomy aka chunkectomy which removed the inital BC and had the UMX to get clean margins and to get other possible problem areas in that breast which were discovered during the MRI I had a week or two before my UMX surgery. I was also told during one of my oncologist appointments that radiation would probably be necessary even with a mastectomy. A final decision for for radiation was made post surgery and towards the end of of chemo rounds. My medical case went before the hospital tumor board several times during my active treatment. I did not have any reconstructive surgery and don't plan to have any . The decision to have or not have reconstructive surgery is not easy....just as difficult as deciding which initial surgery to have. For me, I did a lot of soul searching and thinking about my age (56 1/2 yrs at diagnosis), how I felt about my outward appearance and how I might feel about my body after surgery. and what I was willing to physically withstand. Try to remember that your decision will be the best one for you and only you since everyone is unique and different physically, emotionally and spiritually. Wishing you the best and hope you find some calm and peace.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2014 12:12PM Melrosemelrose wrote: wamoss63- I do understand why you are questioning the need for 3 more rounds of chemo.   Although my situation is different from yours, i viewed chemo as just another means to help make sure that to get those sneaky cancer cells that may be undetected and were not found in any biopsy or tumor pathology.  To me, it is just one more weapon to give me and my body a good chance to be NED. ( no evidence of disease).  Yes, what Holeinone told you is true..... If one is triple negative, at this time there are no additional hormone target therapies ( ie Tamoxifen or Arimidex).   No matter what it will always be your own choice to decide whether or not to continue with treatment.    I agree with Holeinone about getting a second opinion and perhaps having an discussion with your onco as to his recommendation for the 3 remaining rounds of chemo and ask the questions as to what factors have been considered in determining your treatment plan.  The other thing to know is that there are some here who do have neoadjuvent chemotherapy, surgery and then additional chemotherapy so don't think that your treatment plan is unusual.  Wishing you the best and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2012 08:51PM Melrosemelrose wrote: amylovesbubby- Sorry you have had to come to this place because of your recent diagnosis; however, so glad have to find great support and information on BCO.  As you find out more about your treatment plan, it will be easier for you to plan how to gather the family and friends to assist you with your young child.  I know you have probably been doing some reading on the chemo forum boards and have learned about the side effects of the various chemo drugs on the Main part of this website and on the forum boards.   Don't assume that you will experience every side effect listed and those effects will be severe.  Each person's body is dfferent and reacts to chemo differently.   The words "crash day(s)" is what we usually call the day(s) when the side effects may start.   Once you have a treatment plan for the chemo, you will know how often you will receive the chemo ( ie dose dense= every 2 weeks; every three weeks, weekly).  That information will be helpful so that you will know when to have extra help and also help you determine what day of the week you want to schedule your chemo so that the crash day coincides when you know you have extra help available to you (ie the weekends when your husband is not working.)  I know there is a lot of information for you to take in.  It is one day at a time, one step at a time.  I can also tell you being patient all of the time with tests, results, appointments, different phases of treatment is not easy since at times it feels like hurry up and wait.  As you will learn, patience will become your friend as it has become mine.  I know the road ahead of you is not an easy one but it is doable and can be done.  Please feel free to private message me if you have any questions.  I am happy to help you and share with you what I've learned.  I've had a lumpectomy and a unilateral left masectomy and have 2 more rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere chemotherapy.  I'm also participating in the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial and will start Tamoxifen after my chemo is finished.  My future treatment plan is still not set as to whether I will receive radiation or not.  I have a lot of support from family and friends and also have found great support and help through these discussion boards.  Hope this helps you.  Sending you lots of (((HUGS))) and positive calming and healing prayers, thoughts and energy.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 09:23AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Catherine22 & Likeachickadee - I just want to thank both of you for being so honest with your feelings and sharing them here. Although my DH and my two children are in my life everyday and I have many friends, I do spend quite a bit of time alone.  I know that down feeling since there was a time right after my UMX that I felt so pushed by my doctors that I justed wanted to get off this fast moving treatment plan I'm on.   Everyone seemed to be in hurry for me to get more pre-chemo testing and start my chemo a week after my UMX.  Too much, too soon and just overwhelming.   It wasn't that I didn't feel positive about things but I really needed time to for my head to catch up with what was happening to me physically.  I made sure everyone heard me that I needed a little time so I could get right in my mind.  The amount of time was nothing more than a weekend.  I basically took a cancer break and gave myself time to not think about my body, my cancer but everything else in my life.  I can't say that everyday I'm a happy girl but I try.  I do have my periods of crying but look at those times as periods of release and glad I don't hold those feelings in.    At this point of my treatment plan, I really don't give a damn what anyone says or comments about my emotional state or appearance---- this is who I am and if I chose not to interact with someone, it's okay.  I know there are a lot of good intentions by family, friends, well wishers and strangers--- But it will never be offensive to say "No, I can't talk to you now".  I share my philosphy of "NO" with you---- It is not an accident that the two letters in the alphabet, "N" and "O" are sitting next to each other. Both of you have helped me get here.  Thank you.

Yesterday was not a good day for me.  I woke at 4:30 am from a dream that I had a fever.  Yep, I really did have a fever around 99.5.  So I took some tylenol and kept taking my temperature to see if it would go down.  Unfortunately, it didn't stay down.  I went back to bed and go up around 8 am so i could eat breakfast and take more tylenol.  Got the chills and then the fever started spiking up past the 100 mark.  Called my onco and she told me not to worry and she called in some anitbotics for me.  After I finally got the right ones (I'm allergic to penicillan), I took them and the fever dropped.  I"m at the end of the 2 week mark after the latest infusion which means my WBC is at its lowest point.  So today, I feel fine and hope with the help of the antibotics and taking care of myself this coming week, my blood counts will be recover enough to have my next chemo on next Tuesday (June 5).  Just glad my onco didn't tell me to go to the ER--- I've visited the ER on a Sunday after my UMX surgery and it was not fun at all.  All I could think about while I was there is that I was in a germ incubator and didn't want to sit close to anyone. Stayshiny- I fulfilled my hot dog craving last week.  I normally don't ever eat them but gosh the hot dog lunch was so tasty!!! Janie - Sorry your 3rd treatment got you!!!!  Glad to hear you are on the mend!!! onvacation - Hope things are calming down for you!!!  I know you have your infusion this week so I hope you have stayed well!!!! For everyone who has just finished- Happy Dance!!!! For those almost finished - YAY!!!!!  For everyone who has more treatments - We are getting through this---- it isn't we can do this---- we are!!!! As always, minimal side effects for all and a great day!!!!

Lezza13- right after the #2 round, I ate cheese sticks, small chicken sandwiches, a scrambled egg anytime I wanted and mac n cheese.  My husband got baked chicken from Whole Foods and I would slice off chicken to make myself a quick half sandwich.  I'd eat a few almonds,and walnuts when the mood hit me.   I eat bananas, blue berries and oranges everyday.   I found that just eating soup wasn't enough for me so I decided to stick with foods that would keep me fuller.  My WBC counts are good so I can eat just about anything ( no raw shushi)  I also eat sherbet when I want something really cold.  Basically, i eat a lot of little meals and try to not think about how everything tastes.  I can tell when the taste buds are going but I just eat whether I like the taste or not. It definitely is a mind over matter thing when it comes to food. I've got a few cancer cookbooks that have helped me figure out what to eat and when to eat what if and when I have side effects.  The pictures in one of the books are great which always gives me ideas of what I might want to eat. I've also bought a few food magazines just for the pictures in hopes that these things will stimulate my interest in eating.  Weird, right....?  No rain here yet but wish it would!!! Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 03:04PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Halfcan - I had Neulasta shots for Rounds 3-6 of my chemo.  I developed a high spikey fever/chills about 10 days after my 2nd round of chemo.  My onco prescribed over the phone some antibotics for me which helped a lot.  There is an ongoing clinical trial to determine if regular 24 hour Claritin helps to prevent the bone pain from the Neulasta shot.  I got the go ahead from my onco to take the Claritin to see if it would work.  I took regular 24 hour Claritin beginning the morning of the day I would receive my Neulasta shot.  The Neulasta shot is given 24 hours after the chemo round.  I took the Claritin every morning for 9 days.  The clinical trial protocal is for 7 days.  Some take the Claritin the day of chemo and some, like me take it the same day as the Neulasta shot but at least several hours before the shot is actually given.  Here is how the process went for me.  The Neulasta is stored in a refrigerator and comes in a one time only shot.  nurse would hand me the shot so I could warm up the shot in my hand before she gave it to me.  Then she would slowly inject the shot so that there would be less pain from the injection.  Does the injection hurt ?  Not really.  then you wait for 30 minutes to see if you have any kind of reaction from the shot.  If you don't, then you get to leave.   As long as you don't have any kind of reaction,  you won't have to do the 30 minute post shot wait after each shot you get.  I always had the shot given to me in the tummy because I asked for that it be given there plus I had a little tummy fat there.  The infusion nurse said she couldn't figure out why others want the injection to be given in the arm since one can experience a little soreness after receiving the shot.

Karmil710- My pathology report from my first surgery, a lumpectomy which was really a chunk-ectomy (partial masectomy) stated that the HER2 was a +1.  Score of 0 and +1 in the HER2 are considered negative.  My oncologist is the one who explained the HER2 score and also told me about the clinical trial.  Her research coordinator answered my questions about the clinical trial and let me know that at any point in time, I can drop out of the trial.  I am on the BCO thread for the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial but not much action.  This trial started in January 2012 so it is fairly new.

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 11:11AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Mark that first chemo infusion in the record books for me!!!!!  It was a long session but I wasn't surprise.  Lots of papers to sign, lots of time having the process explained and just getting everything started.  I iced during the Taxotere infusion and walked around during the Cytoxan infusion.  I had a one on one session with Look Good, Feel Good by ACS and got the makeup and a wig while getting the Herceptin infusion..  I wasn't expecting the wig but it looks like Marlo Thomas when she was acting that Tv shows "That Girl".  All in all, it was a good experience.  I'm hoping for minimal SE's but I also know that since I'm on that Herceptin clinical trial, I need to immediately call when I'm having any degree of side effects.   I did not get a Neulasta shot and won't receive one unless the situation warrants it.  That will be determined by the next blood check in three weeks.  I drank a lot of water and ate ice like fiend. Now begins the waiting came for SE's---- hope they are minimal and tolerable.  Thanks for the suggestions and guiding me along this path. xoxoxoxoxo

Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 09:13AM - edited May 9, 2012 09:13AM by Melrosemelrose slak - Hope minimum side effects for you!!!  I have noticed my skin is really dry so I try to lather up with Cetaphil cream, not the lotion.   I make sure I put it on my feet/toes and hands/fingers since they seem to be the driest.  I got some cotton gloves from Walgreens/CVS to wear on my hands and wear socks after I lube up my feet/toes.  It's like giving myself a hand & foot massage when I do that.   As for the mouth sores,  I assume you can drink really cold icy water during your infusion to help with the mouth sores; that might help.  You could freeze a bottle of water that is not totally full and then add regular water to it and hold/drink from it during the infusion.  That might be one way to sneak in an icing. HUGS!!!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 11:40AM Melrosemelrose wrote: I know how you feel and was equally surprised to find myself with BC.  I'm pretty healthy person, ate well, sleep well, no family history, no alcohol/drugs, not overweight, etc., etc., etc.   Just as Claire said, no one really knows why any of us get the disease since sometimes there is no exact cause.  However, once the initial shock of learning that you have it, you will learn more about what the facts are with respect to your cancer through testing and conversations with your doctors and what the treatment plan will be.  I know you are anxious and afraid as all of us were at first; however, there is plenty of support and information here on the BCO.org main website and on these boards to help you get through this.    Now that you have come here, just know that you are never alone and you will never be alone as you go through treatment. Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2014 10:13AM Melrosemelrose wrote: blondiex46 - Sorry the benedryl didn't work for you.  I know the inability to fall asleep is very frustrating and to stay asleep just adds to that frustration.  When I didn't fall asleep, I would get up and lounge on the couch with some mindless tv on.  I know that the light from the tv can stimulate the brain which may further interfere with sleeping.    The anxiety of not sleeping seemed to escalate my not sleeping a little more.  In my mind, I viewed the mere act of laying down and resting as a very good thing and eventually I would fall asleep. I would take a nap whenever I could.   As for the steroids, if I remember correctly, I think I had to take them twice a day..... one in the morning and one in the evening.  I would take the morning one with breakfast as early as I could so I would take the evening steroid as early in the evening as I could ( 12 hours between the doses).   If you are still struggling to get some sleep, you may want to chat with your onco.  Hope the sleep fairy finds you soon!!!

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2018 09:26AM - edited Aug 3, 2018 04:44PM by Melrosemelrose elisa60- As with any chemo regimen, the chemo is doable but not always easy. Everyone reacts differently to chemo and so it is hard to predict what side effects you may experience. Hopefully your side effects are minimal and manageable. You may want to check out these 2 cook books that I used while in chemoland. The first is "Eating Well Through Cancer" by Gerald Miletello, MD and Holly Clegg. This book has recipes and helpful tips about how to handle certain side effects . The second is "The Cancer Fighting Kitchen" by Rebecca Katz. That book has tips and recipes. FYI-Rebecca Katz has a Facebook page and website. You can also visit the Chemo section of the BCO Discussion forum and check out some of the threads on Cytoxan/Taxotere. Here is a link to one of them: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topics... I know it is not easy to wrap your head around all of the information that you want to know at once. Too much info at once can become overwhelming.Sending you peace and calm as you prepare for your adventure in chemoland. Melrose

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2012 10:41PM - edited Mar 1, 2012 10:46PM by Melrosemelrose The preliminary pathology report came back 48 hours after my excisional biopsy.  I had the entire cyst removed when the biopsy was performed.  (BTW--It was a pretty large cyst).   I'm sure patience is hard to find right now.  It has become my friend these days as I have more tests (MRI, node testing and whatever else that needs to be done) scheduled. The part of the pathology report that has the estrogen, progestrogen, HER2 was released after that. I went to see an oncologist to tell me about the particulars of my pathology report before I went to see the BS for a followup visit after the biopsy.  He was out of town the week that the full pathology report became available and I didn't want to wait two weeks after my biopsy to go over the results with him  Sending you positive thoughts and hugs.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 07:33PM Melrosemelrose wrote: NurseLeeLee- Sorry the AC chemo side effects are getting you.    1.  I had a different chemo regimen than you so the not so good days immediate after the chemo round is different from yours.  Sorry I can't be of much help but get plenty of rest, keep hydrated and eat healthy. 2.  I received the Neulasta shot the day after I had my chemo round.  I also took regular, 24 hour Claritin to help with the bone pain associated with the Neulasta shot.  I took it the morning I would receive my afternoon Neulasta shot and continued to take it for 8-9 days.  There is an on going clinical trial to determine if the Claritin helps prevent the bone pain.  I got my onco's permission to take the Claritin.  I did not have any post Neulasta bone pain.  3.  I did have a tummy issue after the first round but not severe enough for me take anything.  (I'm one of those people who hates to take anything unless I absolutely have to.)  My onco told me I could take OTC Zantac to help with that if I wanted.   Yes... I took my anti-nausea drugs like a good little girl and never had any nausea issues.  I figured that my onco and infusion nurses had way more experience with chemo and know the first line of prevention for nausea are those anti-nausea drugs.  That is the main reason I took them plus I just don't like having that yuck feeling. 4.  As for diet, yes I made changes.  I ate small meals 5-6 times a day.  A fed tummy is happy tummy while on chemo.  Having food in the tummy helps prevent nausea.  I also was given a cancer cookbook called "Eating Well Through Cancer" written by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello, MD.  That book has chapters on what to eat before chemo, and what to eat when you have certain side effects (constipation, diarrhea, etc.)  It also has recipes and shopping lists which help take the guess work as to what to eat.  Since I'm participating in a clinical trial, I also maintained a daily diary of the foods I ate and the drugs I took.  It made it easier for me to figure out what I eat and ensured that I did eat and help me make sure I took in enough fluids.  I usually ate bland foods a few days after chemo--- my white meals of mashed potatoes/baked potatoes/ mac n cheese/ baked chicken/ baked fish. Just remember you don't have to super duper woman. you can be just super woman while going through chemo.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed in November, have questions! NurseLeeLee Melrosemelrose

Posts.Content: May 5, 2012 08:16AM - edited May 5, 2012 08:17AM by Melrosemelrose Drain holders- I bought several Champion brand front zip athletic jackets (cotton & comfy) from Target ($29.99) that had inside pockets that I put my drains in.  I bought them a size larger so I could easily get my arms into them after my UMX.  I also purchased a post-op camisole from a specialty shop that had removable drain holder pockets.  Check with your insurance company to see if they cover the cost of the camisole.  Your breast surgeon can write you a prescription for those post-op bras/camisoles.  My camisole also came with removable fiber fake boobs that I could adjust the size of the boob by removing the fiber.  If you get a camisole, make sure you are able to step into the garment since taking things on and off over your head may not be possible post-op.  In the shower, I used one of those name tag holders with a clip to clip/pin the drains to.  I also had to wear an ace bandage post op and wasn't able to shower immediately after the surgery.  I sometimes pinned the drains to the ace bandage instead of a shirt. Shirts- Finding button down shirts are not always easy to find in the women's dept.  Head to the men's dept for shirts if you can't find any you like in the women's dept.   Constipation- I have managed to not have this problem post op and during chemo.  I eat Sunsweet Ones (really moist individually wrapped prunes) and drink prune juice/apple juice.  I know the idea of prunes that usually comes to mind is yuck but they really do help.  I haven't had to take any OTC meds for this. Please go to the Surgery section of this forum for more tips and also refer back to the main information section of this site.  You may want to join the May 2012 thread and visit the March and April surgery threads to get more practical suggestions.  Wishing you the best.  You can also private message me if you want.  Always willing to help and support those on this journey as many have done for me!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 09:30PM Melrosemelrose wrote: To All My New Friends-Thank you so much for welcoming me to chemoland.  I'm thinking about starting a new chemo thread for those starting in late April- May with Taxotere/Cytoxan.  The March/April thread is already going and most will halfway finished with their treatments before I even get started.  Thanks for the suggestion about adding the number of treatments and when to the signature.  Question for all:  I was wondering if you chose the day of the week of your treatments or if there is particular day of the week you prefer having your infusion and what time of day.  Just trying to figure out what will work best for me. Heatherb8: After reviewing the data of a previous Herceptin clinical trial, researchers determined that some of the participants were not HER2 what I call true HER2 positive.  They were +1 which is considered negative.  The researchers found that some of the +1's benefitted from the Herceptin.  So the B-47 clinical trial purpose is to examine that aspect.  It is my understanding that  HER2 +1's do not receive Herceptin.  The trial is looking for 3000 participants. Again, ladies, thanks for sharing and I will keep you posted.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 02:15PM Melrosemelrose wrote: I iced my nails only during the Taxotere part.  You can ice your fingers and your toes. If you decide to use peas, do not eat those peas for dinner!!!  Just mark the bag "Do Not Eat" and refreeze them so they can be used at the next infusion. Always clear anything you want to do with your onco.  You will need to clear it with your onco about icing since not all oncos will allow icing during the Taxotere infusion.  At the suggestion of my onco, I am using clear nail polish on my nails to help keep them strong and also icing the nails to help prevent nail damage which is a side effect of Taxotere.  She suggested that use Sally Hansen Strong As Nails Clear Polish but I switched to Essie polish since it doesn't chip as much as the Sally Hansen brand.  Essie polish costs more but for someone like me who never used nail polish before chemo, the fewer times I have to apply polish the better.  I don't mani/pedis but some do.  I'd rather avoid the germ issue at nail salons and taking of a chance of getting nicked.  ICING :

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2012 07:09PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Hello Ladies It looks like my first infusion of taxotere/cytoxan will be on April 24 (Tuesday).  I having six rounds every 3 weeks.  I've roaming through the chemo boards trying to absorb as much as I could about everyone's personal experience.  Well, it's my turn now to get this trip to chemoland started and join in this adventure with you.  I probably would have started a little sooner but I had to have emergency surgery to fix of UMX bleeder on 3/25.  I had my UMX w/o recon and port placement on 3/14 and was doing okay until I got hit with some bad sinus allergies and bronchitiis.  I think the bleeder was caused by coughing too much and too hard.  I got the last drain out today and hopefully will be as physically fit as one can be after surgery to go forward with the chemo.   I'm also participating in the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial which is to determine whether low HER2 patients benefit from receiving Herceptin.  A low HER2  score is a +1 which is considered negative.  HER2 +1's do not receive Herceptin as part of treatment now.  Researchers went back and reviewed the HER2 scores of the participants in a prior clinical trial and determined that some were really low HER2 +1.  I will know at the first infusion if I will be receiving the Herceptin.  It is a randomized study with no placebos--- you either receive or not. Thanks to each of you for posting your SE's and leading the way for me.   Have a wonderful weekend!!!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 09:10PM Melrosemelrose wrote: I saw a breast surgeon first after I referred by my gynocologist.  I had already had a mammogram and ultrasound before I saw the breast surgeon and had a consult with the radiologist as to what the mass might be.  After I had the lumpectomy, I got a referral for my oncologist through a family friend and did not wait for my first breast surgeon to refer me.  He went out of the country the week following my lumpectomy and did not return for a week.  My oncologist then referred me to a new breast surgeon that she worked with on a regular basis.  She later told me that she had wished that I had seen her before I had the lumpectomy since due to the size and location of what was removed would have spared me from having two surgeries ( lumpectomy and unliateral mastectomy aka UMX).  I can't say that there is any requirement that you see a breast surgeon first.  It depends on what you know about your situation before  seeing the breast surgeon and who you know and trust to help you find an oncologist.  I am very very fortunate that my family friend is the head radiology oncologist at a major cancer center hospital where I live.  I have no regrets in switching breast surgeons for the UMX because all of my medical team are located in one place which means it is easy for the doctors to access and share information (test/scan results/ pathology reports) amongst themselves and I travel to one location rather to several offices located in various parts of the city I live in.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 10:33AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Isharvey- You may want to look at your pathology report.  It may have the Ki67 score on it.  Mine did and the number was high.  Here is what the main BreastCancer.org says about Ki-67--- It's under Rate of Cell Growth in the Diagnosis Section. Ki-67 is a protein in cells that increases as they prepare to divide into new cells. A staining process can measure the percentage of tumor cells that are positive for Ki-67. The more positive cells there are, the more quickly they are dividing and forming new cells. In breast cancer, a result of less than 10% is considered low, 10-20% borderline, and high if over 20%.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 01:50PM - edited May 16, 2012 01:51PM by Melrosemelrose Janie- Glad to hear you are feeling better.  Somehow I have managed to dodge the "C" and "D" issues.  As for the "C" issue, I drink prune juice/apple juice and eat some of those Sunsweet One's individually wrapped prunes which are really moist and super sweet.  I also eat every morning a bowl of rolled oats oalmeal with banana, blue berries and Kelloggs wheat bran ( they look like twigs) with milk and a glass of water.  I also try to eat plenty of fruit, fresh veggies, salads for fiber.  No "D" here.  I also try to eat very light meals before the chemo and for several days afterwards--- like rice, mash potatoes, baked chicken, bananas, scrambled eggs, broth, mac n cheese.... things that are easy to digest and not heavy.  I was given a cookbook at the cancer center called "Eating Well Through Cancer" written by Holly Clegg & Gerald Miletollo, MD.  The book has easy receipes and recommendations during & after treatment.  The book took all of the guesswork away for me since I don't have to figure out what to eat when and what to eat when I'm having side effects.    Fortunately, I have not had to take any OTC meds for "C" or "D".  Hope you get better soon!!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 07:26PM Melrosemelrose wrote: jennyrjd- I have been icing my toes nails and fingers nails an dso far so good.  No discoloration or lifting. I also put clear finger nail polish too!!! The icing and clear nail polish is what my onco suggested that I do.  If your onco/the infusion center where you go doesn't object to the icing and polish, I'do it because it can't hurt.  I'm not doing the cold caps although the infusion center does have a special cooler to keep those  caps cold.  If you decide to ice, you need to ice 15 minutes before the Taxotere, during the Taxotere and 15 minutes after the Taxotere.  You only ice during the Taxotere and not during the Cytoxan part. Not everyone knows about the icing.  We know it here on the boards because of the written and reported past experiences of others who have had this regimen.  Couldn't hurt to ask if you want to do the icing and nail polish....  I'm getting the Neulasta shot only because my WBC must have dipped during nadir (lowest time when WBC is at it's low point) and got that nasty high spiking fever during Memorial Day weekend.  I got put on antibotics to give my body a boost to get over whatever infection/fever hit me.  I didn't receive the Neulasta shot for the first two round. I drink super cold ice water and eat ice during my infusions to help avoid mouth sores.  I don't know if you are on other chemo threads, but please stay here if you'd like!!!  I'm having 6 rounds in total and tomorrow (knock on wood that I have good blood counts), I'll be half way  #3-- Yay!!!  Love to have the company since a majority of the gals on this thread are having four and have finished or will finish shortly.

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2012 06:11PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Halfcan- I hope you and your onco are able to get the Neulasta approved.  It is definitely better to have that bone marrow boosting shot than spend time in the ER or in the hospital.  To answer your question, I did not experience any of the bone pain associated with the Neulasta shot.  However, I will tell you that I did have occasional muscle aches/jt pains but that was from the chemo since that is a side effect of my chemo regime.  The pain was never severe enough that I had to take any OTC meds (Tylenol or Advil) or ask my onco for a prescription for pain medication.  Here is a link to the clinical trial so you and your onco can read about it http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01311336?term=neulasta&rank=2 Also, here is a link to chemocare.com which is the website started by Scott Hamilton who is a former Olympic ice skater and cancer survivor.  That website can provide you with a little more information about chemo drugs and their side effects.  After reading the info on my chemo regimen (Cytoxan/Taxotere), I knew that some of the muscle aches/jt pain was from the chemo. http://www.chemocare.com/bio/ I was also very fortunate that I had minimal side effects with my chemo.  Hopefully you will have the same!!!!  If you have any questions, you can always private message me.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 04:02PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Jenny- Glad you have joined us on this thread of just awesome and supportive gals!!!  As Hiker61 said, the anticipation of the first treatment can be overwhelming but in fact, once you are actually there, the first treatment is very doable.  You will also find as that the first infusion make take a little longer because you are being introduced to the infusion procedure .  I also have a port.  If your port area has not healed prior to the first infusion, make sure you ask for the infusion nurse to spray the area with numbing spray before you have the infusion.  After that, ask your onco for a prescription for EMLA cream (lidocaine numbing cream) for you to apply an hour over your port before your infusion.  If you have any questions, please ask!!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 07:51PM Melrosemelrose wrote: I have my chemo on Tuesdays.  The first round, I woke up around 11 pm Thursday night and started feeling just yucky. I got up out of bed and sat in my desk chair which seemed to help.  I also drank some really cold iced ginger ale which helped a lot.  I burped a lot and I mean a lot. I think I had heartburn but too tired, too druggy and not feeling well to figure that out.  I went back to bed after a few hours and woke up Friday morning feeling really groggy from the Activan I had during the infusion.  I was offered the Activan to help me keep calm so I said "YES".  No constipation or diarrhea---- just crazy burping.  The second infusion, I had less burping and felt tired on Saturday this time.  I also ate more protein (chicken, eggs) that time and kept my tummy fed and hydrated.  Started to lose my short bob hair on Day 15 after the 1st infusion.  That following weekend, I took the scissors to it after making 5 short pony tails to be used later if I want to make a hair halo.  There are instructions on the chemo forum somewhere.  My DH got his trusty electric clippers with a 1 inch guard and cut and cleaned up what I had done.  It was a very short short boy hair cut.  I have yet to shave my head bald since I am curious to see what hair (aka Elvis) goes and when.  I haven't lost any more hair in a week and heading into Round 3.  Since I am in the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial for HER2 (+1)'s, I have to document everything ( side effects, food, temperature) so I can provide as much info as I can to my onco and her research coordinator.  One big science project here.... lol I know it is amazing that so much has happened in a relatively short period of time.  I'm glad things keep moving forward for all of us!!!!  I used to say I can do this--- now I am doing this.

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2012 05:20PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Sorry to hear that you have developed the hives after your third round.  I am a little surprised that your oncologist  doesn't think the hives are related to the chemo because anyone can become allergic to any medication at any time.  The side effects of the chemotherapy drugs are cumulative so your body may be letting you know that it is hitting its limit.  You may want to go to drugs.com and look at the side effects of the Cytoxan and Taxotere.  As for the 4th round, I would ask what pre-chemo drugs you will be given in your IV just prior to receiving that 4th round.  I also would keep a diary/calendar noting the date when the hives started, when you notified your onco, the location and severity of the hives.  I also would start keeping a diary of everything I ate, washed clothing in and just about anything I came into contact with.  In short, document your symptoms and what you eat, have touching yor skin and perhaps you can track down the source of the hives.  I would also tell the infusion staff at your 4th chemo about the hives so they will be watchful during the infusion.     If you have read some of the earlier posts here, you will see that some of the gals on this thread have experienced the hives from their chemo.  I fortunately, have not but have had the hives from antibotics and foods since my BC journey began.  I know you are frustrated with physically not feeling well from the chemo and now the uncomfortableness of the hives.  Keep your spirits up since the hives are not a permanently condition and can be controlled with the meds you have been given.  You are almost done with the chemo!!!!  Most of the other women on this thread have moved on and I may be the only that is still having chemo.  Like you, I have only one more round to go.  Good Luck!!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2014 09:13AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Everforward-  Take some deep calming breaths..... you are okay and not alone.  I know you are anxious and very shortly, the specifics of your situation will reveal themselves through testing/ scans.  Before your next onco appointment, you may want to write down all of the questions you have about what your treatment plan will encompass.   At that appointment, you may have more specifics about the pathology of what was found which should help explain your onco's treatment plan for you.  Yes, the size and pathology of what was found are determining factors as what your treatment plan is.  At that time, you may also want to let your onco  know of any other health conditions that you may have since these health conditions may affect what type of chemo regimen you receive. FYI: I am a participant in the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial where HER2 +1 and HER2 +2 are randomized to receive Herceptin.  Under the current drug protocal, only those patients who are HER2 +3 receive Herceptin as a part of their chemo regimen.  I was fortuntate and had minimal side effects from my chemo regimen and did not experience any noticeable side effects when I was receiving Herceptin only.  I had 6 rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere every 3 weeks and received the Herceptin infusions every 3 weeks for one year starting with the 1st round of chemo.    I finished chemo August 2012 and the herceptin March 2013.  I've been on Tamoxifen since September 2012.  I can't say that my treatment plan has been a walk in the park; but I can tell you that having a positive attitude and educating myself as to how to take care of myself are just two of the many ways that I feel I have done my best to get through the active treatments. Wishing you the best..... keep breathing...... Sending you positve calming and healing thoughts and energy.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2013 11:57AM Melrosemelrose wrote: carla53- The Neulasta shot helps stimulate the bone marrow to produce cells.  Your white blood cells (infection fighters) and red blood cell counts may drop after each round of chemo.  The shot helps the body make more white blood cells to ward off infections which one is susceptible to while on chemo.  It definitely is better to have it than having a trip to the ER or having a short hospital stay because of an infection.  As for the ice, the ice helps prevent the mouth sores.  The chemo affects body cells that are renewed more often, like the ones in your mouth.  The sucking on ice during the infusion may help prevent or lessen this side effect.  You can also rinse your mouth out several times a day with the following mixture of salt and baking soda and water.  Just remember to make a fresh batch every time you rinse.   1/4 teaspoon salt + 1/4 teaspoon baking soda + 1 cup of warm water. I had the same chemo as you are having-- Cytoxan/Taxotere.   I would get my chemo on Tuesday.   I felt fine the first 36-48 hours after receiving my chemo.  On Friday, the 3rd day, I would start to feel the downhill slide.  I usually drank ginger ale and lots of water and rested as much as I could.  I would rest over the weekend and would feel okay by Monday.

I ate one to two prunes with every meal which helped me a lot.  I reached a point where I couldn't face another glass of prune juice so eating them was the next step.  I ate those Sunsweet Ones prunes which come individually wrapped and really moist and sweet.  You can get them at Target on the shelf near the raisins/baking supplies. Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2012 11:42PM Melrosemelrose wrote: Christina- I had a lumpectomy on my left breast  in February 2012 to remove what was thought to be a large cyst.  Instead, it turned out to a a rather large cyst that contained IDC and DCIS.  The lumpectomy was really a partial masectomy which is where more tissue is removed than a lumpectomy.  The surgeon got close margins on 3 of the 4 sides so it was necessary to go back in to get clean margins.  I switched breast surgeons and opted to go with the surgeon that my oncologist suggested and works with on a regular basis.  It wasn't an option for me to have a re-excision lumpectomy because of my small breast size.  It was hard at first to accept having a UMX but I have no regrets.  I had my UMX without recon in March.  The breast surgeon told me that it was not advisable for me to immediate recon because I had developed a breast infection in the breast I had the lumpectomy about 10 days before my scheduled UMX.   I was somewhat relieved when my breast surgeon said no recon now because I was becoming overwhelmed with so much happening and information with my situation.   I'm in my mid 50's and at this point, hadn't really thought about having recon.  My recovery from my UMX has been relatively easy and have regained full motion of my left arm after my sential node biopsy.  I'm in the middle of my chemo and may or may not have to have radiation.  I'm trying to focus on one phase of my treatment at a time  so my mind can keep up with what is happening to my body.  I can understand how overwhelming and confusing how you feel when so much is coming at you at once.  The information you have about your situation, the better you can make the best decision for you.  Wishing you the best.  Sending your postive, calming and healing prayers, thoughts and energy and reassuring HUGS that you are not alone on your journey.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2013 11:44PM Melrosemelrose wrote: GainsvilleSpouse-  So wonderful that you have come here and asked for some support and help for your wife and you to get through her time in chemoland.  You have found great place for support and information and where there are many who have travelled this way. Here is the link for the BCO Chemo Threads for Newbies where you will find the links to several chemo discussion threads that are very helpful and include tips, more tips, head coverings, wigs, port placement, etc http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/785189?page=1#idx_1 If you are wanting to know more info about her chemo, you can go to the main section of BCO.org and find info her type of chemo.  I also used chemocare.com as another source of information about the side effects of each type of chemo.  This website was founded by Scott Hamilton, the one time Olympic ice skater who is a cancer survivor.  Here is the link:  http://chemocare.com/.  One of the things that I found very helpful was to keep a food diary and medicine diary.  The food diary helped me figure out what to eat and what worked best for me during time between chemo rounds.  The medicine diary was to help me keep track of what anti-nausea meds when and how much.  I amde sure that I took my anti-nausea meds on schedule and that the same times with plenty of water and also with food.  The reason for the taking them with the food is that some of the antinausea drugs can cause nausea if taken on an empty stomach.  I also noted on a calendar how I felt after each chemo so I could keep track of my side effects and when I felt not so great. As for eating, I tried to eat 5-6 small meals.  That way, I always had something in my tummy which made me less likely to experience nausea.  I also had two books to help me figure out what to eat and probably can be found on line at Amazon or Barnes & Noble Eating Well Through Cancer by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello MD ( has tips, how to deal with side effects, recipes, shopping lists, menus) The Cancer Fighting Kitchen by Rebecca Katz- ( tips and great pictures and recipes) As for the Neulasta shot, I had those beginning with my 3rd round of chemo.  I had the shot administered in my tummy since there was a little fat and not as painful as it would have been if I had received it in my arm.  I also took regular 24 hour Claritin the morning that I would receive my shot in the afternoon.  I continued to take it for 7 days which is the protocal for the current on going clinical trial on the taking of Claritin to help the bone pain from the Neulasta.  Just remember that your wife's type of chemo may also cause muscle aches and joint pains so one cannot always assume that the Neulasta is the culprit for aches and pains.  As for the hair, this is a very personal thing.  One does know that the hair will most likely go but until it actually begins to happen, the reality of the event can be upsetting.  It is the most outward evidence to others that one is not well.  We all have our hair stories here and we each dealt with the change.  I wore bandanas, Buffs, baseball caps, and straw hats purchased from Target.  I had a fee wig that I received through the American Cancer Society's Look Good Feel Good program which I decided not to wear because it was too hot.  You may want to check to see if there is an upcoming program for your wife to attend.  They also have a makeup session where one receives a free bag of makeup and can learn ways to tie head scarves. As the two of you travel through chemoland together, please continue to come back here for support and help.  Both of you are not alone and there are plenty of wonderful people here ready to help you.  Wishing you the best!!!

I know it may seem like an inconvenience to travel to a major hospital with cancer center or a major cancer center, but you will find that the medical staffs are more willing to help schedule everything together and not have you drive back and forth.  At the hospital I am going through, it has a cancer cemter and oncology navigators to help introduce the patients to the cancer center and help patients get additional help with keeping track of their medical information, social services available and other things.  The staff makes an effort to welcome every patient/family that comes through the door feel comfortable  and know that they are there to help the patients.  Every time I have had schedule appts with several different doctors, efforts are made to have the appts all in one day.  I hoping you find a place like this because your mother,you and your family will benefit greatly from feeling comfortable with the medical team and the surroundsings.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2013 02:15PM - edited Dec 2, 2013 03:52PM by Melrosemelrose You may want to have a significant other or good friend accompany you to your appointment.  Sometimes having an extra set of eyes and ears helps plus that emotional support will also give your spirits a boost.  Take paper and pen so you can take notes during your appointment.  Sometimes one doesn't necessarily hear everything that is being said during the appointment.  You may also want to prepare a list of questions so that you get questions that may be swirling in your head answered by the oncologist.  Here is a link to the main BCO.org website in the Diagnosis Section that may help you prepare the list of questions.... http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/diagnosis/dr_questions and here are the questions themselves... You may want to start a notebook to help you keep track of the medical info that you are collecting as well as have a month to month calendar so you can write down your appointments for doctors and any additional tests.  Yes.... you  can ask for copies of any of your test results.  If you have time, make a lists of all of your doctors, closest 24 hour pharmacy, medications, prior surgeries/hospitalizations, food/drug/substance allergies.  You will find having all of this information handy will make it easier when you are filling out forms. You may also want to visit the main BCO.org section on Treatment and Side Effects.  Here is the link to that section and you can read up on what is a treatment plan and the components of a treatment plan ( Ie surgery, chemo, radiation, hormone therapy, etc.) http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment. Good luck and wishing you the best.....

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 05:12PM Melrosemelrose wrote: lles- I know the feelings you have all too well..... you feel like the train is leaving the station and you are trying hard to catch it because you know you need to, not necessarily because you want to.  It's that rushed/hurried feeling that is sometimes difficult to deal with.  I had a lumpectomy which was really a partial masectomy to remove what was thought to be a large cyst.  Surpise.... it wasn't a cyst after all but encapsulated DCIS and IDC and Grade 3 which meant cells were growing abnormally and quickly.  I met with my oncologist a week after my lumpectomy and also changed breast surgeons.  My current breast surgeon ordered an MRI of both of my breasts to see what else may be lurking.  I did have to have a uni-lateral mastectomy (UMX) to get clean margins later on.  I did not have the right breast removed since my onco and the tumor board said that since the right ones was healthy, I did not need to have it removed.    I had 6 rounds of chemo (Cytoxan/Taxotere) and no radiation.  The no radiation decision was determined by my onco and the hospital tumor board that reviewed my case.  I also am in the Herceptin B-47 clinical trial to determine if those with low HER2 positive scores of +1/+2 benefit from the receiving Herceptin. ( HER2 +1 and +2 are not eligible to receive Herceptin under the current drug protocal and are considered negative for Herceptin purposes).   I am also taking Tamoxifen because I am ER +.   You need to know that because you are ER+ and HER+3  your onco may determine that  Herceptin and Tamoxifen/Arimidex (hormone treatments) are a part of your overall treatment plan. I know you are frightened and scared.  Take one day at a time and one step at a time.  The facts of your bc will reveal themselves as time goes on.  Please know that you are not alone and you will find plenty of support, understanding and information on the BCO.org main website and on these boards.    FYI:  Here are some tips to help you post lumpectomy-After I had the lumpectomy, I used an ice bag (ziploc bag of ice) that I had placed in a fleece travel neck pillow case ( had removed the pillow) to keep the swelling and pain down.  Try to take your meds on schedule so you can stay ahead of the pain.  Make sure you continue to eat so that you don't get nauseous from taking pain medications.  Drink fluids.  Try to rest as much as you can. Wishing you the best..... Sending you lots of HUGS and positive calming & healing prayers, thoughts and energy.  You can always private message me if you like.

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2012 01:45PM - edited Dec 9, 2012 01:47PM by Melrosemelrose lles-  Keep coming back here for support and info you need!!!!  We are here for you and no apologies need to be made here for how you feel!!!!  We know how you feel and have been where you are at right now.  I know it isn't easy and this does seem to consume your mind.  Please be easy on yourself and do give yourself a break from all of the cancer info and talk.  It doesn't matter how long that break is ( 10 minutes/ 30 minutes/ an hour.....)--- do something to help to take your mind all of this ( shopping, watching a funny movie/tv show, read a magazine, go for a walk)----- Get out and breathe a little.  As for your treatment plan---- you may want to post a thread on this forum or on the chemotherapy forum or help me get through treatment forum asking about doctors in the area where you live.  You can get a second opinion by any doctor and don't feel awkward or uneasy about pursuing the other opinions.  You have to be comfortable with your medical team and your treatment plan.  (FYI:  I switched breast surgeons after my initial lumpectomy.  I was a little scared to do that at first but in the end , it was the best decision for me and I have no regrets.  If your intuition is saying to find out more and get other opinions, follow your instincts.)  HUGS!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2013 10:38AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Indenial- Just wanted you to know that there are people here who had minimal side effects with the chemo.  I am fortuante in that I was one of those people.  I did my homework and reading before I started chemo to help lessen my fears about chemo.  I was given some general info about my chemo regimen but decided it was best to get more info, especially from those who had the same chemo as I was going to have.  You may want to join one of the current chemo threads so you won't feel alone.  The comaraderie and support you will find on the chemo threads are an immense help.  There is a Cytoxan & Taxotere Chemo February-March 2013 Group which I started as that request of one of the gals here.  Please feel free to join us on that thread.    I was given a copy of the book" Eating Well Through Cancer" by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello, MD which has food shopping lists, menus, recipes and what you can eat when you have certain side effects ( ie sore mouth, constipation, etc.)  It was good to have a reference book handy with tips as to what to do.  I also had slight constipation off and on but I took care of it by consuming high fiber buik foods, apple and prune juices and prunes.  You also need to make sure you drink plenty of fluids & water.   Yes, I know the idea of eating prunes is not appealing but they worked.  I drank so much prune juice after my UMX that I couldn't look at another glass of that.  So I ate the Sunsweet Ones which are individually wrapped dried prunes which are really sweet and moist.  I ate one-two of these prunes after each meal.  You can buy them in a plastic canister at Target; they are near the raisins at Target.  Wishing you the best and hope you are healing well from your recent surgery.

Posts.Title: Pain on day 7 after 1st chemo treatment. What can I do Kathie100 vballmom

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2013 08:46AM Melrosemelrose wrote: Before you call yourself a big baby again..... remember that your onco is there to help you with your side effects.  It is the onco's job to and it doesn't matter what you call him/her about or when you call.  You just call and don't let any of the side effects get out of hand.  I know you were told that you may feel like you have the flu; however these are not necessarily side effects that you can ride out and think they will get better on their own.  So please, make that phone call and get some help. For the mouth blisters-- rinse your mouth several times a day with a solution of 1/4 teaspoon baking soda + 1/4 teaspoon salt + 1 cup of warm water. Make sure you make a fresh batch everytime you  rinse. For constipation- Sometimes the anti-nausea prescriptions (Zofran) can cause constipation.  You can try to eat foods that help prevent the constipation.  I ate for breakfast a bowl of rolled oat oatmeal plus banana, blueberries and wheat bran and milk.  I also ate a few Sunsweet Ones (which are individually wrapped prunes that are sweet and moist) after each meal.  When eating more foods with bulk, one needs to make sure to drink plenty of fluids. To help you figure out what to eat when dealing with certain side effects, you may want to check out these two books--- Eating Well Through Cancer by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello and The Cancer Fighting Kitchen by Rebecca Katz.  I have both of these books and found them extremely helpful.  The first book has great tips, food menus, shopping lists and recipes and is divided into what to eat before chemo, how to deal with certain side effects ( constipation, diarrhea, sore mouth etc.)  The Cancer Fighting Kitchen book had wonderful pictures and good recipes.  Again, these books were very handy to have on hand, especially when I needed some immediate information. As for the Neulasta bone pain, are you taking a regular 24 hour Claritin (OTC med) the day you receive your Neulasta shot and for 7 days afterwards?  The Claritin may help prevent the bone pain from the Neulasta shot.  There is an ongoing clinical trial about the taking of Claritin to help prevent the bone pain--- http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01311336?term=claritin+neulasta&rank=1 . Ask your onco about taking that.    I told my onco about the Claritin and how the clinical trial.  She gave me her approval to take it and fortunately, I didn't experience any bone pain.  At the same time, just remember that one can have muscle aches and joint pain from the chemo itself. Hope you feel better soon.  Keep us posted!!!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 05:41PM Melrosemelrose wrote: StrongMe23- dlb823 brought some very good points about using the breast surgeon that is suggested by the gynocologist.  My first breast surgeon was the surgeon recommended by my gynocologist.  At that time, I was overwhelmed and thought that the lumpectomy I was going to have was just to remove a large cyst.  However, it turned out to be something much more.  After I received the Friday afternoon phone call from the breast surgeon that it was cancer from the initial pathology, it became very clear to me that I needed someone with more experience and needed to consult with an oncologist before any more future surgery took place.  Over the weekend, I called some family friends who are oncologists and got recommendations.  I had my first appointments with the oncologist and my current breast surgeon the following Thursday and moved forward with them  As for the first breast surgeon, he was out of town the week after my surgery when I saw my oncologist and breast surgeon.  I talked to his office about who is refers his patients to for breast cancer and didn't especially like the cancer consult group he would send me to.  I also did not have the impression that he had enough experience dealing with my situation.  Since I did not want to wait with getting facts about my cancer and treatment so I moved on.  I have no regrets changing surgeons because it is in my best interests to get the best top-notch care that I can.  No harm ever to get a second opinion.   Again the fact that all of my medical team is in one location, under one hospital with cancer center has made my life so much easier.  I don't have to worry about getting myself from appointment to appointment in different parts of town and all of the doctors have access to all of my medical records.    I know this is a lot to digest but again, take it in small doses.  Sounds like you would like to get a second opinion and would like to see the oncologist/ another breast surgeon before any further decisions are made. Second opinions/ consults never hurt and can provide you with additional information that will help you.  The doctors know patients do get second opinions.   No matter which doctors you see, you will still have the questions that you have and are formulating about treatment.  If you break it down this way, you can see the path and not be so overwhelmed.  I'll keep checking back here so if you need any more help, everyone is just a click away.

I switched surgeons ( the first one did a lumpectomy) and have no regrets.  Another reason I switched surgeons was because the oncologist and the breast surgeon both work out of the the hospital system where my cancer center is.  It has made it easier for me to go to one medical complex with one hospital that has access to all of my medical records/tests.  It is one day at a time and one step at a time.  The waiting part in the beginning is hard and patience is hard to come by.  It feels like hurry up and wait.  Patience will become your friend as it has become mine.  When you do learn more information, please refrain from googling.  That is a lot of information out there and it will just overwhelm you.  Once the treatment plan is in place, your mom and you will feel better.  Wishing both of the you the best!!!
